151295957.review:
I wasn't sure if this was my sort of game at first, because I get scared very easily - and this actually put me off from playing this game for a while after I encountered one of, if not the only abnormality jumpscare in the game. I did regain my courage and try again at some point, though, and I'm very glad I did!

This game is stressful, but in an enticing way. The missions and dealing with abnormalities as a whole can be extremely tough, but for the most part, feel quite rewarding. It can sometimes punish you for getting too attached to your employees, which is not something I am usually fond of, but I think in a game like this, it only adds to the experience instead of taking anything away.

The overarching story of the game is interesting, but I feel like it shines most in the lore of every individual abnormality. Each of their stories are uniquely thrilling and horrifying, and it honestly does make trying to complete the codex very enjoyable. The art style and character designs are quite nice, but once again, I feel like the abnormalities (mostly) take the cake with their unique and terrifying designs.

Overall, I think the game is pretty neat :)

150602417.review:
[h1] This review contains no-spoilers, Tl;Dr at the bottom [/h1] 

Lobotomy Corporation is one of the most fun games i have ever played, its also one of the hardest, that "difficult" tag is not lying during your first play through you WILL have to restart the week, that being you lost a lot of employees or you got an abnormality that is too difficult to contain, your first play through will have at least one restart (and that's where i find some of the charm of this game), so this is a basic review for someone who has stubble onto this hidden gem of a game

[h1] Whats the premise of the game? [/h1]

This is a Tycoon/manger simulator that is based of the SCP foundation, each day you get a new abnormality, varying in difficulty, to competed a day you need to work on abnormality (4 types of work, some are better than others on certain abnormality) to get Enough E-box to pass the day, using said E-box can be researched to discover more about the abnormality and its habits or use to acquire armour and weapons, with some armour/weapons being able to deal more damage/take more damage while doing less/Being vulnerable to other, there are several other cogs that make this game work that im not getting into, if you want a new-player guide/you are expecting a new player guide, this isn't it (i might do one if this review goes well)

[h1] Whats the Story of the game? [/h1]

(Without getting into spoiler territory) a basic intro into this game, you are the new manager of lobotomy corporation, a company that uses AIs and employees to farm Abnormalitys for their energy, your new job is to insure nothing goes to shit, i could explain more but this is a story that's better if you don't know anything going into it

[h1] Should i get it? (rating) [/h1]

Absolutely, although i "complain" in the beginning that the game is rage inducing, pretty much all of the time it was your fault, you didn't read something correctly, you didn't suppress that threat immediately, you were lazy and didn't check all the abnormalitys for danger and for that and

[*] a great sound track

[*] Amazing visuals

[*] A good game play loop

[*] Creative and unique designs

[*] and unique remixes of already created Characters (fairy tales)

Lobotomy Corporation is a 9/10, 

Tl;Dr: Lobotomy corporation is a very fun but rage inducing game that i think alot people should try

150551700.review:
This game is good if you like management and high difficulty games. You will need patience especially when you're trying to figure out what is each abnormality and their method of management. The game CAN be easy, but you won't get the proper ending. And if you try to get the proper ending... expect getting wiped several times. Good thing is, even if you lose all your employees, you can still succeed with a new batch, although harder. Although you can retry the day, or relapse to an earlier memory if you find yourself stuck.

The story is interesting and this game has two sequels now, one is a TBS (Library of Ruina) and the other is a TBS Gacha (Limbus Company)

149677013.review:
Originally, I thought I was going to dislike this game, and truthfully, I did! However, after progressing further in the game, I realized: "Holy moly wait this game is actually so good"

It has the perfect amount of lore to keep you interested and keep you progressing through days, the perfect amount of gameplay - both strategically and difficulty wise - and learning all these new Abnormalities and what they do is a great feeling. Sitting there with the game paused for minutes on end, just thinking of what to do in order for your Agents to not die a brutal death is a wonderful feeling, and the stress gained? It's such a great feeling as well.

Overall, while Lobotomy Corp may not be for everyone, it's definitely a game worth checking out if you're a fan of the SCP Foundation, or just a fan of strategic games like Civilization or Fallout Shelter.

i have edited this review to be an actual review with my actual opinions:
The OST is genuinely one of the best I've ever heard, because the second and third warning OST can make you feel like you're going to need to restart your entire game, but genuinely all of the OST is really good.
The Abnormalites are all original and genuinely some of them are really concerning, and annoying. (MAGICAL GIRL FUCK OFF)
Despite only getting to day 19, the story is really good,
That's all I have to say about the story.
The gameplay can sometimes be like "take all employee and supress abnormality.", but sometimes you have to put strategy into what E.G.O gifts some should have, the weapons, the suits, and the strength ening and promoting of employees.
Difficulty can vary to easy to restarting back to day 1, so overall it has a nice range of difficulty.
My final score: 8/10.

I would recommend this game to anyone. It broke me. It rebuilt me. I'm ashamed of what I became when I played this game, yet, never before have I gained such power. I should have reset to day one the moment I got D-01-106 at day 12, as noon or dusk events would inevitably kill clerks which would inevitably release the bitch who would then kill everyone. We were too weak then to fight back.

And, and yet, somehow, I persisted. I ascended. I rushed execution bullets. Starting waiting for clerks to overlap so I could take out 3 or so at once. Would spend the first few qliphoth levels spamming bullets just so I could clear out all the clerks. Once they were gone, then the true day could begin. By day 35 I had trauma-bonded with my nuggets and refused to let any of them die, and we were past fearing what a mere army could do. Memory reposited more times I could count in order to 100% the abno records without having to do a full reset, and to do the "boss" missions without losing an employee. It was madness. It was unhealthy. I should have just let them all die.

What did I do it for? What hollow satisfaction? When I spent two hours in the winning attempt battling T-03-46 with a single surviving employee I knew in my heart that once this challenge was conquered there was nothing left but to reposit one last time and then finally take on the end game. By god, I did it. But I was empty. What left did I have to live for?  My friend told me there was a sequel. With tears in my eyes, I realised maybe it didn't have to be the end.

But then, as I examined the steam store page, horror filled me, greater than hearing the popping buzz of a bee or the drop of second trumpet ever could, greater than hearing "I love you" repeating in an eerie childish timbre. 

The sequel is a card game.  :(

Otherwise game is amazing, 12/10, do give it a try!!! There really is nothing like it <3

148861306.review:
[h1]Every abnormality has a weakness. The wise manager trains for what they will face.[/h1]
Lobotomy Corporation takes places in a parapsychology research company responsible for supplying energy to a metropolis called The City. You are the manager of the aforementioned facility and your responsibility is the training of your agents and ensuring the production of energy. The energy, denoted 'Enkephalin/PE boxes', results from the interaction between your agents and eldritch creatures called abnormalities. Each abnormality has a work preference, and it is your job to discover their preferences to facilitate the efficient energy flow.

[h2]Some may fall, but their knowledge lives on.[/h2]
One of the essential parts of the LobCorp is that your agents are disposable. Your main progression comes from the gear you acquire from the abnormalities you work with and the missions you complete that are given to you from your subordinates. Another part of the game comes from training your agents, your agents gains stats depending on the danger level of the abnormality, the damage they receive and how successful their work is(how many PE boxed they produce). You are going to be resetting a lot, which also resets the stats of your agents, so it takes less priority until you collect enough gear and complete the missions.

Lobotomy Corporation is a long-winded journey that rewards you with great lore that piques your interest, including very memorable characters that are sure to leave a mark on you. It took me about 143 hours to completely finish the game in a blind playthrough, and despite the hardships that I had to face I can say with the confidence that every single minute of my playtime was worth it.

148693519.review:
I genuinely really wanted to like this game as a big fan of SCP-style stuff, and I do think this game's story and lore is its greatest strength. If that's all that you're looking for, and you can stomach the grindy aspects of Lobotomy Corp, then I would absolutely recommend this game to you.

For me though, the grindiness just isn't to my taste. The game isn't mechanically diverse or complex enough to really differentiate days from each other in the same way that other roguelikes like Binding of Isaac do, and the management aspect of the game becomes very simple once you've trial and error'ed your way through the different monsters' traits.  

It ends up being very repetitive, especially given how long days end up getting near the end. There are various boss fights and random combat events to spice up each day, but the combat feels too clunky for those to be enjoyable, at least for me.

A lot of this is personal preference however, and ultimately I don't hate the game. If Steam had a better rating system, I would probably rate this game as mixed, or 3/5.

148680409.review:
UPDATE:
The more I play Lobotomy Corporation, the more I hate it. I don't think it's fun that the fanbase wants everyone to look up the wikipedia. That takes me out of the game. I like to [i]discover[/i] how things work, but everything here just feels cheap, unfinished, and full of padding.
Additionally, I feel like this game is wasting my time. You are encouraged to play perfectly, or reset days, and there are plenty of possibilities that you can get stuck rerolling the dice on whether something dangerous is going to break out and kill everyone, the further you go. If you don't play to an A or S rating, you WILL get stuck, eventually. Plus, the vague epitaphs of the SCPs you unlock are rarely clear on what danger grade they are. You can't even see it until you unlock enough information on them, which is only available after working with them, which is only available after many resets of trial and error. This is [i]why[/i] fans direct newcomers to the wiki, but it's just bad design.
I've seen a post in the forum complaining how the game is too easy, and they're on Day 19. 
First off, the more SCPs you get, the more likely you'll get harder ones.
Secondly, I got to Day 17, and have at least two world ending difficulty SCPs in my facility that make it nearly impossible to manage. At this point, I'd have an easier time if I restarted to Day 1, but again, that's just not fun. The story wouldn't change, considering that it's a visual novel narrative, unlocked by progressing missions for each department.
Yeah, definite thumbs down. As cool as the concept is, and as much as it hurts to say this, Lobotomy Corporation is just a bad game.

ORIGINAL REVIEW:
I'd give this a mixed button if it existed.
I want to give this game a thumbs up, but its "Gotcha!" mechanics piss me off. There'll be a lot of stuff you can only do through trial and error, and while some of that is fine, there's so much of the game that is pure trial and error. The problem is, when all is going well, the end of the day goes to hell, where you had no warning on what was about to happen. This forces you to restart entire game days, or lose your items and advantage for future runs. If employee deaths were less punishing, this wouldn't be so bad, and further encourage exploration without resetting the day. However, Lobotomy Corporation encourages resets. Lame.
Some elements of the UI are cumbersome. There's unnecessary headache.
All this said, the story is great so far. The concept is interesting. I just think the execution of gameplay is sub-par.
[strike]Additionally, this game does not save after every day, so you can't just play it in short sessions. You have to put an hour or two of your time in every game, or leave the game open.[/strike]
IMPORTANT: Sometimes the save system works, and sometimes it doesn't. It might be more consistent by going back to the menu at the beginning of a day. After you "Begin Management", Reset the Day, then Go Back to the Menu.

148048493.review:
[h1]All of Project Moon's games have excellent ideas, but poor execution.[/h1]

Lobotomy Corp. and LoR both suffer from extreme mechanic bloat, poor pacing, frustrating mechanics, pointless grinding, and a complete lack of elegance. It really is a shame, because they're also some of the most interesting and creative games that I've ever played.

[h2]Bloated Mechanics[/h2]
There are so many different ideas, it feels like the game is going all over the place. Both games feel absolutely overwhelming when starting out, unless you spend the time to read everything. Usually, this isn't a problem, but both games introduce many mechanics, often without a proper tutorial. There are many mechanics that are one-offs, or entirely redundant. LoR is especially guilty of this, introducing a new Keyword almost every new invitation in the mid-game, and not adding any useful support pages for existing Keywords. Lobotomy Corp isn't free from this either, as the novelty of adding a new anomaly to your facility wears off after you collect enough boxes to fully understand how to manage them (usually before the day even ends).

[h1]Poor Pacing & Pointless Grinding[/h2]
It's no secret that Project Moon games have poor pacing, with sharp difficulty spikes. Again, this usually isn't an issue with most games. I spent 4 hours learning all of Margit's attack patterns in Elden Ring, because I decided to rush through the game as a low level wretch. Even if it was difficult, beating him was immensely rewarding because I could feel myself getting better as time passed. In both Lobotomy Corp. and LoR, most problems can be solved if you spend enough time on it. If you want to play efficiently, both games get boring very quickly. In Lobotomy Corp, there are multiple situations in which you can hard lock yourself into losing the game and you lose about 2 hours of progress because of it. Not only that, but you really have the option to grind for E.G.O gifts and boxes if you want to unlock everything by the next day. I want to be managing my anomalies, not waiting for drops when I know there's no risk involved. Still, this pales in comparison to LoR's book system. Even after multiple revisions, it's still incredibly grindy. The decision to not have all of the pages unlock once you beat an invitation is absolutely awful from a design perspective. The game is already quite long for an indie title, and adding in grinding heavily takes away from the experience. It only serves to slow the gameplay down, so you're not absolutely overwhelmed by the next new crazy mechanic that's just right around the corner. It gets even worse when we get to the bosses. Boss fights can take up to an hour, and you're rewarded with nowhere near the number of books that you need to actually get all of the useful cards that you want. It's a massive grindy time sink for literally no reason. The [spoiler]Purple Tear[/spoiler] pretty much made me quit LoR because of the amount of time I would need to spend grinding in order to beat the next invitations.

[h1]Frustrating Mechanics & Lack of Elegance[/h1]
This is probably my biggest issue with Project Moon's games. The amount of time you spend not playing the game usually exceeds the amount of time you're actually doing stuff. This is a shame, because the stuff that you would be doing if you were just playing the game is usually quite interesting. Having individual decks for all of the Librarians is interesting, until you realise how much time you just spent creating 15 decks so you can beat the next invitation in LoR (of which I can usually beat first try). To a lesser extent, this is also visible in Lobotomy Corp., as every single agent has their own resistances and you need to pay attention what goes where, depending on the abnormalities they're going to be working. If you want to win, it's a whole bunch of reading, and not a lot of playing.

I just want to say that I really love both games. I love the world, I love the music, I love the ideas in both games, but they have so many issues which make it impossible to recommend them. There are so many roadblocks put in place for you to just not enjoy the game, which wouldn't have a harmful effect on the game if they were removed. You're punished by playing optimally, because it just ends up in optimising all of the fun out of the game. It's a known meme that LoR players don't know how to read, but perhaps they're better off that way - they have less to think about, and would rather think it's all decided by dice rolls.

146810729.review:
Lobotomy Corporation is an anti-capitalist sci-fi horror rougelite + monster management sim. ProjectMoon calls out The Cabin in the Woods as a core inspiration and oh god it shows in such a fun way. The game places you in an underground facility where humans experiment on and extract energy from monsters known as “Abnormalities”. There’s over a hundred funky little freaks each with harrowing backstories and super interesting designs. Each day you choose from 3 monsters to unlock, and you have to figure out how to extract their energy without dying in the process.

The gameplay loop is real good for sure, but I couldn’t actually beat the game. I put 20 hours in and saw that it would apparently take 100 hours to beat, and I’m not that strong-willed lol. I’m not a speedrunner and I’m not the kind of guy who looks at really complex puzzles (like the extra stuff in The Witness) and goes “oh yeah, I’ll make 100%-ing that game my life for the next 4+ months” 😂

But despite the length, I really did enjoy my time with it! I ended up watching the rest of the game on youtube because I haaaad to see how it ended!! The meta story of the game uses Kabbalah and Jewish mysticism in the same way Neon Genesis Evangelion used Christianity as a basis for its crazy apocalyptic world building. Its so creative and engrossing and I wouldn’t shut up about it for at least a month

146669812.review:
Review coming from someone who beat the game with the true ending 

Lobotomy Corporation is an incredible concept that is horribly horribly botched in execution. 

There are so many tiny things that pile up to make the experience worse. 
The performance is TERRIBLE
Tons of information is needlessly hidden, forcing you to either repeat the same operations over and over through trial and error or endlessly consult the wiki (I did the latter and am very glad I did)
The balance is all over the place, and is generally very unfair and hits you with a bevy of cheap tricks that aren't communicated to the player well

The good is there though. The story is excellent, the setting is fascinating, the characters are super interesting and get a ton of depth. The soundtrack while limited and repetitive over 100+ hours, is REALLY good, and the setup for the sequel is amazing. 

I can't in good faith recommend playing this game to anyone, but I am very glad that I played it if only because it'll make me enjoy playing Library of Ruina (a good game) a hundred times more

Never pick the train

How to survive anything*/how to become the Taliban (Spoiler Free)

Before you send brave freedom fighters to glorious battle against the infidel (Before you start a bad ordeal or open up the cage of a funny Aleph, or worse)
Purge the infidel from your own land (Kill all clerks with execution bullets)
If thou does not have the righteous tool of allah, and the infidels gather strength from the blood, pray to him (If you don't have execution bullets and a abnormality that escapes after deaths, pray to god and hope you can take the domino flood like bigweld)
Send the weak and vulnerable to sanctum (Send all low level employees into a single elevator)
Gather the mighty and zealous (Gather all high level employees in a different elevator, maybe with one or two scattered around abnos that are at risk of breaking out and would lead to domino flood)
Ensure that the infidel does not grow more powerful as you strike them down (Make sure that they don't absorb/are immune to certain types of damage, split em up into either a seperate strike team or just condemn them to the crying corner where the low levels are)
Send forth the righteous call for Jihad (Send one employee to open the door/start the event)
Engage in prayer to Allah, and he shall grant his protection to smite the foul agents of Shaitan (Bullets pierce your employees, letting you grant a shield to all of them at once if they're stacked together in an elevator)
Ensue in glorious battle using all means for the glory of allah, he has granted us the mighty caverns and mountains as our shield (Use strike force as situation calls, whether that be just slowly clearing the facility department by department, hit and run, or some cheese, elevators let you move to dodge attacks the fastest)
The weak and fragile should not be forgotten, for they shall sow the seeds of allah for tomorrow (Keep an eye on the weak/crying corner if they are at risk, move up/down the elevator to dodge/run as needed)
Allah's mighty Malāk shall come to the aid of the faithful if they only call and serve Allah (Use mercenaries liberally, farming energy is usually rather simple and safe)
Allah shall grant victory to those that eternally fight for his glory (Lobotomy corp is a hard game, and even with a good strategy it could take some tweaking/retries, to get it all right. Patience is required for many of them, never fight face-face unless you have an overwhelming advantage)

*Do not let the infidel sneak and lurk where he shall sow his seed of heresy (If the ordeal/abno teleports around and causes meltdowns, you do have to split up and cast a wide net)
**Those who have not properly done the rites of Allah shall find themselves broken and bleeding with his absence (Actively train your employee's skills, don't end the day as soon as you get the energy required. More boxes = more xp)

145483071.review:
This game is great and all, but this is the type of game where you are almost required to reset to do good in it. When you unlock gear from the abnormalities you work on (excluding E.G.O gifts), you can reset to day 1 with all that gear that you have as well as any permanent upgrades you get from facility upgrades and other particular events I wont mention due to spoilers. The true ending also requires you to fully research every abnormality that isn't made by a patreon backer (they have a circle instead of a square icon on them) which also adds to the difficulty of trying to 100% it. I heavily recommend getting some mods to help with the struggle, such as gift chance boost, special EGO information, HPbar stacking, Recustomization, free customization, and a few other quality of life mods that make the game way easier to understand as well as giving you more freedom in some of the things that dont impact gameplay. The story is the best part due to its deep world building present throughout the different games and comics/novels the game has.
 
Difficulty: 7/10
Replayability: 5/10
Fun Factor: 6/10
Story: 9/10, lots of reading and no voices
modability: 6/10, not too much in form of new content, but there's tons of apperance and quality of life mods.

143923451.review:
[b]This game will bully you with impossible situations.  Restarting from Day 1 is NECESSARY.[/b]

A few things carry over each time: The names/details of abnormalities you've fully studied, and Core Suppressions.  Without spoilers, Core Suppressions are 1 of 9 boss fights that you will challenge on certain in-game days, and these will unlock permanent upgrades and protect a part of your facility from RNG.

Your strategy will be to, in each run, learn as much about different abnormalities as you can, challenge a core suppression, and restart.  The game will get easier and you'll get further into the story, because when you're provided with a list of abnormalities to add to your facility each day, you will know how to handle them and the lethal combinations the game will try to bait you into. 

Very good game and story, but will drive you crazy.  If you are a perfectionist, you will [b]suffer.[/b]  
There is no such thing as a perfect run.  The employees you come to care for and raise will be slaughtered by situations you can't foresee or control.   Like balancing a bunch of spinning dinner plates, once one falls, the rest can and will too. The game drills into you the sense of "acceptable losses", and how you can't save everyone, and doing so otherwise is completely mad.  You will waste senseless amounts of time if you try to save everyone, and you need to learn to swallow your pride and handle the losses you'll face, and recognize when the game is telling you to restart or try a different approach.

143435170.review:
This game is very stressful. But that's part of what makes it so good. And if you mess up, its not fun. but thats not necessarily a bad thing.

Its very much about management but not just numbers, you have to memorize each abnormalities info to a T or else you're pretty much ****ed. And that's like, 50 at a time.

Its incredibly hard. But its also really rewarding once you know what you're doing.

The translation especially for the abnormality texts is really off. Its charming, but kind of hard to understand whats going on for quite a few of them, or maybe I'm just illiterate.

And once the energy cap required for day end increases into the hundreds it can get pretty boring, especially on repeat playthroughs which is needed for completion as its a soft-roguelike.

The art style is cute and simple but I kind of wish it was a bit more disturbing or less restrictive for the abnormalities in particular, cause the horror isn't really there for most of them, at least in my opinion.

The story is really interesting and engaging, but it being locked behind tons of incredibly hard challenges is a bit annoying, I can imagine its worse for people who aren't too used to management games or extreme difficulty in general.

Its good, especially for a studios first game. Im pretty excited to play the next installment in the universe. But its a bit exhausting to put dozens of hours into a game like this, but I realize that's my fault, lol.

142993771.review:
this game is mentally exhausting and that's fun

But in all seriousness, you probably won't finish this game and that's okay. Long story short, Lobotomy Corp is an incredibly consistent yet frustrating game of Simon Says. Do exactly this and that, and you'll do great, but if you deviate even a little, forget something, time to start over. 

The game does a fantastic job of layering rule upon rule that you'll need to integrate into your workflow and it's a lot of fun to manage, but it requires 100% of your attention at all times. The challenge is good, but it's a pretty extreme challenge after a certain point and I personally decided to give it up around Day 30 as I was getting to a point where it took me a dozen or more attempts to progress another day. Plot's great, characters are great, absolutely recommend it if you're willing to put in the work.

142643453.review:
This is an exceptional experience that dares to challenge you in ridiculous ways. It is both frustrating and rewarding to play blind. It will literally destroy your mental and physical health. I've left a positive review, however I really would not recommend playing this game unless you're an experienced gamer without AHDH who is good at optimization and willing to whip out the wiki after a couple days in.

If you're trying to play this game to prepare for Library of Ruina but you're a casual gamer, give it a whirl on sale for 10-20 in-game days but, for your sake, watch a story video on youtube for the rest, or just read a synopsis. The true ending/epilogue is Not possible to do for most gamers for these reasons:
[spoiler]
- There will be Bosses that hard punish you for Pausing the game, which is a fundamental mechanic for not losing your mind keeping track of all the abnormalities you need to keep in check
- You will randomly forget one of the 50 "If you break this rule your Agent simply dies" abnormalities in your massive base
- Each day will get exponentially longer as you have more Agents, more facility levels, more abnormalities, and higher quotas to fulfill, AND there is no save state/quick save for the game so you could for example lose 2+ hours of work for a single day (multiple times) because of one random screw up you forgot about and have to start it all over, with different RNG
- And all this aside, the game is simply just hard. You HAVE to optimize or else you will fall behind. You can start a new run with some things that you've earned but idk, who has that kind of time (a complete run will take you 70-100 hours allegedly)
[/spoiler]

tldr: Wait for sale, go in blind (but open up guides and wiki once you feel mentally stressed), and stop and watch youtube / read a synopsis after you hit a wall. Unless you're a pro gamer without ADHD with months to spare, in which case go nuts. Its a very interesting experience, it just comes at a mental and physical cost irl!

142642150.review:
The theme is cool. It's fun to see the monster designs, they make you wonder what they're capable of.

Sadly the gameplay loop is barebones and punishes the player for playing the game without providing any significant decisions to make.

Losing high level characters is basically the fail state of the game, it slows down the progression to a halt and you have to start the day, or the last 5 days over again. 

This game has no such thing as "playing well". Doing everything right means that you don't die and there's no way to gain a sense of momentum. The rewards are passive equipment and stat upgrades. 
You gain nothing special, and when you lose what you have you won't even feel an ounce of regret or sadness, but the stifling obligation to start over.

The arbitrary stat types (Instinct, Sanity, Temperance, Justice) are obscure and have no effect on gameplay or your playing style other than dealing different colors of damage and taking care of different colors of monsters in a rock-paper-scissors way. Being better at something barely changes the way a character plays. The way you approach a creature is nearly always the same. This is a game of 4 categories and lacks any meaningful mechanics.

This is like a base management game without any base building. No planning involved at all.
The combat is as shallow as an idle game minus the fun skills and unique equipment.

The events that happen randomly have no relevance to the creatures you contain in your facility. The monsters that spawn during an event, unlike your monsters, won't give you any information about how you deal with them. So it is not even trial and error but pure luck and confusion at that point.

There isn't any real reason to have multiple monsters other than the fact that the game forces you to do so. Otherwise you can just generate energy from a single one, they're basically cows that you have to milk and all they give you is the same milk. Although each monster visually has very distinctive features, this doesn't reflect into the gameplay. Your characters don't recieve their powers, don't gain experience from taking care of a type of entity. They don't specialize, they mean nothing to the player.

There is really not much point exploring this game. I can't see why you wouldn't just open a wiki page and play it that way. Or you can just read the wiki and skip playing altogether.

142637105.review:
Edit: as of 2023.07.26. it turns out the company that made this game and is actively updating a live service gatcha currently, is run by korean neckbeards. Pirate this game, don't buy it.

Bad game, painful to pay. I'm a masochist.

No but real talk. This game scratches that SCP urge that the lack of SCP based games leave inside you. If I were to talk about the positives I'd be here for days so I'll just list a few negatives:

* One of the most prominent negatives you will read about the game is the way music is handled. TL;DR, there are states called trumpet states, which essentially let's you know how fucked your facility is currently. Here comes the issue. Ideally, you want to keep the trumpet level low, but that means you will listen to the exact same 1:30 loop of "neutral" music. Even if you reach first trumpet, the music takes ages to build up and by the time it does, you already dealt with the issue or you are off to second trumpet.

* Handling employees. While initially (first 20 or so days) it's, fine, the game quickly starts throwing stuff at you that requires the utmost perfect micro to not lose half your facility. Issue is, if you have two employees overlapping with eachother or an enemy, you will not be able to individually select those employees, only the top one. This is an issue when most ordeals do aoe damage and require half an army to take down. Multiple times I lost employees unnecessarily because I couldn't micro them (or even see their healths) in the middle of combat, which is a bit frustrating. (I also lost an entire save file to this issue while dealing with my first Dusk ordeal)

* Upgrades. The first 12 or so upgrades are very questionable. You are literally unlocking basic Quality of Life features like seeing your employees' current health or what type of damage is being dealt to who under the name of "upgrades". It's only after fully decking out the Information Department that you kinda start unlocking actual upgrades and after day 20 that you start unlocking the good stuff. It took me 30 hours to get to the good upgrades by the way (heavy skill issue I guess).

* Researching new abnormalities. While this issue is very early game, it's still kinda frustrating. You are supposed to not know anything about a new abnormality, essentially forcing you to gamble with your employees. Oh what's this, my employee died and also made the abnormality breach with a single work because you have zero idea if that work is the ideal one or not? Skill issue, time to restart the day. If you want to play the game optimally, you either suffer or play wikipedia simulator, which is lame. Later when you have high level employees, this issue goes away partially, but it's still not fun to realise that an abnormality instantly kills your employee and breaks out if you do one specific work that you didn't know.

* Bugs. Some abnormalities just straight up don't work. Specific example: SO CUTE!!! Everytime she breaches, she ends up running in place making it trivial to supress.

From reading this it must look like I hate this game but consider that I have these few negatives in a sea of positives and I still love the game and I can see myself reaching the 100 hours mark in no time.

142036978.review:
In perseverance, there is both agony and triumph. Perseverance is the key to Lobotomy Corporation, in both navigating its gameplay and fulfilling your role in its intricate story.

You've probably already learned this from the other reviews, but to reiterate: this game is [b][u]HARD[/u][/b]. While the first few days may seem like a cakewalk filled with repetitive gameplay, you will soon find yourself entangled in a double-layered web of a quickly thickening plot and an ever-expanding facility containing deadlier monsters. The challenges ramp up significantly as you encounter story-relevant "boss battles" that can push you to the limits of adaptability. This game will slap your carefully planned routine out of your hands and laugh as your employees die horrible deaths as they scramble to suppress monsters that you [u]SWEAR[/u] you were monitoring carefully, but weren't. You will even come to find that certain basic game mechanics that you absolutely took for granted have turned out not to be a right, but a [i]privilege[/i] (here's looking at you, Atziluth residents).

The experience can seem punishing and unforgiving. The roguelite mechanic is integral to progressing past seemingly impossible roadblocks. Whether you activate the "memory repository" and rewind to the beginning of a week, or restart completely from Day 1, your facility and employees will be reverted/wiped, but the gear you have bought and information you have learned will remain intact. Sometimes, the only way to overcome the game's challenges is to reset and return with more experience in mind and better armaments in hand.

Personally, what pushed me to power through all of the trials and tribulations the game has to offer was its intriguing story. With every cutscene, you are left to piece together the past and ruminate on the future lying ahead for everyone involved with the corporation. There is a glimmer of hope hidden underneath all of the chilling, depressing, and forlorn moments in the plot. The way it ties into the gameplay at times does make you feel that you are "facing the fear" to "build the future" (ha ha). Your own experiences managing the facility can also end up as entertaining anecdotes; you will certainly find several in other reviews.

Lobotomy Corporation is certainly not for everyone. It is a game of trial and error, of accepting your failure, and of persevering in search of the light at the end of the tunnel. Those who are not fans of management games may find the basic gameplay loop to be boring. Those who hate trial and error may find the virtually-necessary resetting to be tedious and overly grindy. Those who dislike stories that are vague and metaphorical may find the plot to be overly convoluted, drawn-out, or outright confusing. And anyone can be a victim of the game's programming, which can be... jank at times (memory leaks are a commonly reported issue). For what it's worth, I was able to complete the game with almost no issues, but your mileage may vary.

If you're someone who enjoys glory through struggle as well as management games, then give Lobotomy Corporation a whirl (I recommend going in blind). You will likely quickly come to learn whether you love it or hate it.

Lob Corp is the type of game that seems super fun in concept -- and really, the concept is pretty cool. Almost everything about this game is either awesome or at least interesting: the setting, the story, the characters, the music, the monsters, etc.

The main gripe is the gameplay. The core loop of the game itself. It varies between mind numbingly boring or simply too difficult to bear through. Cheating through guides and/or knowledgeable players is basically mandatory, and even then it hardly feels worth it. 

It feels as though it was very close to something I would've really enjoyed. That feeling of disappointment and missed opportunity is the only thing I can feel about Lob Corp.

141107304.review:
I got baited into playing this game because a friend thought I would love the world that Project Moon had built after seeing it through Limbus Company, parading it as essential to understanding the basics of what is just Korean SCP. He was right, I did like IP a lot better after this game, but I will say full stop that if someone got you into this game cause the PM lore is amazing and you should get into it, get off this steam page and go watch a story recap. This game is not worth only the story if you can't get through the gameplay.

The game is a management sim, and some give it the title of roguelike because of the mechanic to restart to checkpoints or the whole game with your acquired information. You manage monsters with 4 types of work and occasionally they break out. This work is required because the game is divided into days that need an energy quota from that same work each day. Progressively, the quota and the risk of the monsters you handle increases. There's a small equipment system, and that's it. That's the whole game.

This game at face value is all about information. If you look things up, the experience will be spoiled drastically, as the mystery of figuring out what you have to deal with be it monster or otherwise is an exhilarating feeling. However, playing blind is also grueling because you end up throwing bodies to figure out exactly what you have to deal with, or you get blindsided midday and have to reset 30 minutes of progress. People that moan about the difficulty of Project Moon games are exaggerating, but this game isn't easy. The last few hurdles the game puts you through are challenging, and many people get stumped at the last stretch. If you know everything that is contained in your facility, by all means you have every right to handle anything that the game throws at you.

If you don't enjoy RTS games or at least the kind of gameplay that comes with them, don't play this game.
If you don't want to spend hours upon hours retreading days of progress, don't play this game.
If you don't like problem solving or strategizing with the bullshit this game sends your way, don't play this game.
This game is only worth it if you want to personally earn and learn the lore of Lobotomy Corporation.

For that specific reason, this game is definitely worth it, or maybe consider it on sale.
The few gripes I do have:
Replaying days is boring and a waste of time once you get far enough and reset, it's just speedrunning to the end of each day without the action to action planning you might have done the first time around.
The game isn't designed to be beaten in one go, and you should know that before you play.
Things like [spoiler] WhiteNight and Apocalypse Bird [/spoiler] are completely optional and can be missed if a player is ignorant or simply skilled/lucky enough. No clue if there should have been things hinting at them or their consequences.
[spoiler] The fucking idiots that designed the last two departments need to be fired. [/spoiler]

141013048.review:
At 279 hours I have officially completed the game in its entirety.

Is this game hard? Yes. It is a game about trying, essentially, to trip up the player. It's a rube-goldberg machine of carefully calculated dick moves. There's an evergrowing list of rules with each abnormality you get: some very simple, others frustratingly complicated, but there is a list for each. For any rule, there is an abnormality with the exact opposite rule: some will punish you on Bad results, others on Bad or Neutral. Some will punish you on [i]only[/i] Neutral, some on Good or Bad results. The game will generously keep track of these rules as you discover them, but you are drawn endlessly into the web. You will get comfortable with these rules in time, but just as you get comfortable the game will begin to alter the deal, and your prayers that it not be altered further will fall on deaf ears. "Is it hard?" You know in being a Korean game it reminds me a lot of Starcraft and the Korean fascination with that: Starcraft is desperately hard, but if you know what to do, and can perfectly execute it, it's easy. If you can't, well, you'll endure. Restarting and Resetting are major game mechanics without which the game cannot actually be completed (literally it is not possible to complete the game in one run without at least one memory reset).

Is it interesting? [i]Desperately.[/i] The story told by Lobotomy Corporation is one I very much enjoy and one that draws you, the player, in as the participate. There aren't choices to make though; rather, the only choices are the ones you come up with to meet the challenges. For the game weaves the story and the difficulty together, as you, the Manager of this strange facility, desperately try to comprehend what it is that you are doing here and why.

You will come to love your agents, you will suit them up in a variety of colorful equipment, and you will send them to their horrible deaths over and over and over. Decapitated, eaten alive, flattened like a pancake, ripping off their own head, dragged to hell, digested by spiders, turned *into* an interdimensional spider, turning into a giant mushroom, turned into a small slime, turned into a large slime, vaporized, pulverized, incinerated, frozen, ground into meat chunks, killed by their fellow agents after they lost their minds and had to be put down, executed with impunity by the manager... and this is not even nearly close to the many deaths you will see them suffer. You will reset and do it again. The charmingly horrible deaths are a balm of sorts: I remember a desperately frustrating death, but watching the individual in question lower themselves into a bath full of blood and grimly deciding I needed to keep going with the day is part of the experience.

This game can be clunky, it's not exceptionally polished, there are infrequent graphical glitches and a few bugs that I had to go and install mods for (it's not necessary to do so, but I wanted to). This game will not be an easy experience, but if you are willing to Face the Fear, and Build the Future, you will enjoy it. I think that this game is [u]unrelenting[/u], and absolutely uncompromising, but slowly bending it to your will until you stand at the end over a pile of corpses and regrets in bloody triumph is one hell of an experience and one I am so glad I decided to play.

[i]Dedicated to Hana, Architecture Team Captain, alongside the other 11 agents killed on Day 49. Never forgotten.[/i]
[i]Also dedicated to Dia, The Heretic. Gave the ultimate sacrifice too many times.[/i]

140932405.review:
One of the best management simulations with a rich story. If you like SCP related games you'll love this game. Lobotomy Corp. also builds the foundation and atmosphere for ProjectMoon's other titles, Library of Ruina and Limbus Company. ProjectMoon goes HAM on the lore aspects and soundtrack of the game.

Content advisory. This game touches on many dark themes and topics such as suicide/murder/drug use.

Pros : 

The world ProjectMoon has created with it's 3 games is nothing short of incredible. Multiple story arcs and endings give Lobotomy Corporation good replay value. Well worth the $8.50 USD sale price.

The OST for this game is an absolute banger. Whether or not your little homies are getting eviscerated or you're watching a dialogue intermission about how one of your empathetic decisions caused the massacre of everyone in an entire sector, the music does an amazing job at setting the tone.

Create your little guys and try to keep them alive... I promise you, you wont. But then again, you can always restart the day... Or turn back time... In a world where nothing is seemingly impossible due to monsters(Abnormalities) born from the sins of mankind, you're always within arm's length of a different possible outcome. However, the price is almost always too great.

The monster management is fun and pretty unique. Every abnormality has it's do's and don't's. One of them likes peeking out from a keyhole and is a little shy. If you watch him, he'll breach and turn your employees into a bloody mist with his sawblades. But if you pan the camera away so he's off-screen he's completely docile. Each new subject is rather fascinating in it's own unique way.

Strategy is key with management and suppression tactics. The E.G.O equipment researched from abnormalities acts as sort-of a rock-paper-scissors mechanic to exploit weaknesses as well as protecting your "little guys." More sectors opens up more perks for employees and containment cells for abnormalities. After later sectors open you'll have access to direct intervention via "bullets" you can shoot employees and abnormalities with which can buff, heal, or kill. Then there's the Rabbit Protocol... for when the big F-U is neccesary.

Check out the Manga, Wonder Lab, which ties into the lore of Lob Corp. Trust me they go hard on the lore and this manga is pretty damn good.

Also check out the [ Limbus Company ] Official Promotion Video. The OST track from Mili - In Hell we Live, Lament Feat. Kihow from Myth and Roid goes hard.

Oh yeah... The Cons : You goan' die.

TLDR : Yes. 9.5/10

140657461.review:
I will never bitch about smt 3's difficulty ever again.

Lobotomy corp is the game to play when you have NOTHING going on in your life for a bit.
Unemployed? play it. friends out of town on your week off? play it. house sitting? wow, free house. if you have ANYTHING going on, your life is happy and you should continue to be without it.

Never in a million years though should you feel guilty looking at a guide or wiki for a hint. this games difficulty is unapologetically unfair. I 100% the game myself, had I not had someone who previously finished the game twice be willing to get me back to a certain point after losing over a weeks' worth of progress, I would've put this game down and never looked back.
There's plenty of cool things to experience throughout the game, buts its difficulty being as it is, I'd call it ultimately as being just short of a masterpiece. the amount of whats there being designed solely to waste your time and piss you off is genuinely unnecessary.
I'll say it a million times as a quick side note for the devs going forward, taking away the players ability to pause the game or adjust the game speed is not a challenge. its inconvenient more than anything.

some frustrating features aren't even based around playing the day to day game. when you mess up or want to try again, you can hit a simple retry button and get all your stuff back you lost at no penalty should you do it.
However theres also an option to go back in time a couple of days in case you really got stuck. for whatever reason, using this option in order to try again will punish you, but the normal retry wont. If you hit retry, then on the prep screen proceed to go back in time a couple days anyways, no punishment occurs. So I ask, why does it matter what screen you hit memory deposit on? one punishes you but the other doesn't I'd like consistency. 

occasionally too, glitches occur. there's not many, and most you'll encounter are simply visual hiccups that aren't too distracting such the game text switching to korean for a single, very specific screen. the one's that are a bit a more irritating to get, put you in bad situation.
examples of this include:
-characters being put to sleep but an entity known as void dream have a chance of just not being able to be interacted with. Meaning, because the character is still bearing the "uncontrollable" status ailment, proceeding to the next day will count as them being killed.
-end game bosses messing up when transitioning to their final phases, and just being softlocked. taking no damage, not moving, you're just stuck at the final hurdle.
-using skill points in increments of 60+ (yes, you will do that in this games economy) occasionally have the tendency to just not give you the buffs after spending them
 
Should you hit any of these pitfalls yourself and put the game down, I do recommend at least looking up the story online. if theres anything this game absolutely crushes, its the writing. Sound design is a good second. I wouldn't say its worth stomaching the difficulty for alone, but hey, its by far the most entertaining thing here.
There are completion rewards of course, though anyone whose finished the game will tell you, completion is practically the only way to really finish it.

final verdict: 6/10
TLDR, this game sucks, but in a "I'm finishing it because I'm not a bitch" way.

Still here?
you've likely finished the game and are looking at reviews for the memes, god bless you sir.

-gebura is just a red haired version of 2B from neir.
-beating this game has gotten me one step closer to playing limbus company and seeing the majesty that is Don Quixote and I couldn't be happier.
-this game got my brother interested in reading classic literature.
-I got a certain white themed abnormality to spawn at 2am right before going bed and wanted to slam my head into a wall
-I was tricked into thinking this game gave you a stupid "good job" certificate when you beat it and I feel robbed.

140649877.review:
I find it pretty difficult to recommend this game to people because of a few main reasons. One, the sound design is poorly balanced and sounds really really bad in a few key areas (looking at you red dawn). Two, the gameplay is very repetitive and also has a very bad case of savescumitis, which only worsens as the game progresses to the point that I really don't recommend to anyone to commit to finishing it. And finally, a lot of aspects of the gameplay, in particular the difficulty are quite CBT and not in the fun ‘throw yourself against a problem until you figure it out’ way.

	On the other hand, the game is incredibly creative, interesting and above all UNIQUE. In my opinion video games are at their best when they do things that other games dont do, and to do that one must take risks and potentially fail. Lobotomy corporation took a risk and for the most part didn’t quite stick the landing. It still made something memorable and hopefully the concept of an esoteric monster facility management sim can be taken and iterated upon by another developer with more technical skill and time.

	Let me go over the flaws again before I dig into some particularly interesting concepts and design decisions I like. The sound is atrociously balanced. Some sounds are too quiet or nonexistent (there should be audible feedback for employee deaths besides the sounds of their various kills, like how Frostpunk has a church bell that rings once for every death. If you’re not focused directly on an employee when they die, there is no way to tell besides the toast on the left hand side of the screen, and if they’re a clerk you get no notification at all!), and some sounds are way too loud! The sounds for the different fixed events, that being the dawns, noons, dusks, and midnights are much too loud and earrapey. Some idle sounds of monsters are also too loud, namely Nothing There (which like, I understand being that Nothing There is supposed to be very threatening, but they dont need to be that loud to do that!) but also a few others. That said the sounds themselves are usually just… fine. Some stand out goods, some stand out bads, but mostly everything is just how it should sound and nothing more. 
	I dont really need to go too far into the game’s bad case of savescumitis, just that its there and it is a lethal case. Thankfully the game does give you quite a few ways to save over and reset from your mistakes, but I feel this is more of a bandage for a wider problem of unforgiving gameplay rather than a positive. 
	And as for that difficulty, oh god. Losing anyone is a HUGE negative due to the time cost involved in getting each employee even up to snuff. This really overlaps with darkest dungeon where employees are supposed to be disposable and you’re not supposed to get attatched, but conversely to that goal, employees are very very expensive to train. Even with all of the bonuses you can unlock to improve employee training speed (one of which requires a quite difficult boss!) it can still take a good 30 or so REAL TIME MINUTES at max speed to fully train ONE employee in ONE in game day. And that entire time you are generating risk of death, and micromanaging to avert the risk of that employee dying, or worse. You can multitask and train more than one employee at once, but there aren't that many abnormalities in the game that are good for training employees, and no gym or equivalent slow training. All employees MUST be live trained at ALL times. You can spend your employee points to strengthen the employee's stats but it's very expensive and really not worth it. So you spend a ton of time on each employee so that you can have a base of workers and warriors that isn't muppets… and then you get blue midnight or some shit and they all die instantly because you didn't pause the game the instant that you sent Urist McUseless to go train on One Sin. And then you reset the day. Hence the bad case of savescumitis. 

	But what’s really good about this game? Well, its fucking cool. All of the monsters feel esoteric, weird and interesting and it's super fun to learn how they tick and how you can incorporate what they do into your gameplay loop. I’d go into examples but that kinda takes away from the fun of it all, and plus I’d be restating what you could easily read on the wiki if you actually care.
	The story is also a highlight, being a pretty interesting concept although not the best written. The characters are fun and interesting, there’s an element of mystery and also quite a bit of that sweet sweet ludonarrative harmony (*gags*). Lots of the themes in the game and how frustrating it can feel is mirrored in the gameplay, and vice versa. Elements of the gameplay are integrated well into the story, such as the cognition filter explaining why the game looks the way it does. (Which also is incorporated into a cool abnormality! If you know, you know.)
	The old testament theming of the game is also quite interesting and unexpected for a game like this. The first abnormality you get in the game kicks off this theme, and is iterated upon by the most threatening one. The characters are themed after biblical (angels? I don’t know much about this. Might be more jewish rather than christian as well.) and it's well implemented. The story also goes into this in interesting directions, in particular the themes of suffering and original sin being mirrored in gameplay somewhat. The theming of this game is original, intentional, and tightly woven into the experience. Very well done.

	Speaking of, by far my favorite part of the game is the warning level. If you fuck up in some way, either by letting an abnormality loose or having employees die, the warning level increases which plays BANGER MUSIC and also has some minor gameplay effects. For the most part, the warning level is a gameplay way to signal to the player how messed up the facility is and also cause a snowball effect of failure. I don’t like the snowball factor that much, but it is in the end interesting which is the end goal of any game. 

	
	So yeah, kind of a messy review. I really can’t say I recommend picking up this game off of steam. If it was free, I’d say it has interesting ideas that are worth experiencing, but if you want a game from this company of a similar or higher quality level that's actually worth your time and money, I’d more recommend Library of Ruina… even though I despise it and everything it stands for due to it being a Turn-based RPG card game deck builder. 

	Overall, here are my generalized scores that arent really relevant to anything but my own general thoughts on the game. Don’t compare these to scores from other people or even myself on other games. 

	Personal scores: (Overall about a 7-8.5 that fluctuates depending on how cool i think nothing there is that day)
		Fun: 6/10 dwarf fortress does CBT better
		Autism-ility: 8.5/10 was my hyperfixation for a while 
		Aesthetics: 7.5/10 accurate corporate hellscape 

	Somewhat objective scores: (Worse than the sum of its parts due to its overall low budget and poor usage of that budget. About a 4 overall)
		Sound design: 4/10 red dawn.
		Game Feel: 5.5/10 aggressively mediocre but buggy. Commanding an army of goobers is never not satisfying but it toes the line in this game due to how janky combat is.
		Game performance: 3/10 holy fuck how do you fuck this up that bad
		Writing: 8/10 story stuff is fine but the stuff that's hidden in flavor text is great
		Horror score: 8/10 can be actually spooky at times
		Art: 7/10 has a style and is just… fine. Game looks bad. 
		The grind: 2/10 is real. And bad. 
		Theming: 8.5/10 Goes for something particular and nails it even though it's not that fun of an idea.

140565999.review:
Lets start off by saying that this is a pretty niche game and is definitely not for everyone. If you want a casual game to play without too much worry, this is definitely not it. This is one of those games where you get better at the game from failing over and over again and learning from the failures.

The best way I can describe this game is... do you remember that laboratory from Stranger Things? Where they discover monsters, ghosts, and supernatural beings and then they experiment on them? Yeah, this is that. You play as a manager and you manage your employees by placing them in a cell with a supernatural being called "Anomalies". You place them in a cell and pray to god that the monster is in a good enough mood so they don't either rip your employees head from their shoulders, make your employee kill themselves, or make your employee kill others. 

Every monster has a "catch" or gimmick that you have to discover and then follow in order to keep your employees safe and make it to the next day (level). Every day you get a new monster, so the real trick is to juggle as many gimmicks as you can so you can make it to the next day without any casualties. 

There is definitely a learning curve and it is true that the game gets easier the more runs you do. Definitely pick it up if you like puzzles and don't mind a little cartoon horror

140025186.review: I think most of the game is pretty solid conceptually, the trial and error of figuring out what's going on with a new abnormality or tool is kinda fun if you don't mind starting days over a couple times to get your footing. Keeping containments under control is a bit nebulous, sometimes I feel like I've gotten a breach without really understanding what or how it broke out, but for the most part as long as you've got enough invested in its research you can suppress a breach without too much issue. But where the game really falls apart in my opinion is the ordeals. Every day for the most part at a random point, some kind of monster will spawn in multiple places throughout your base. There's no information on what kind of damage they do or how they attack or really anything at all as far as I can tell, and since they're completely random there's no real way to prepare for them at all. I've had multiple days where some new ordeal just shows up and the monsters murder a bunch of agents before I have any idea what they even do. It just really pulls me out of what is otherwise a pretty fair trial and error experience.

139950066.review:
It's times like this I wish steam had a "neutral" option for reviews. Lobotomy Corporation seems like another case of a really cool idea ruined by poor execution and design choices. At first glance it has all the right ingredients for me to pour several, replayable hours into it: solid base-building mechanics, good artstyle and music, and an intriguing paranormal setting that's basically the SCP universe in everything but name. 

Instead, I couldn't get past some of the more questionable design choices. It has haphazard UI scaling and font sizes, and there's an overuse of SCP-like jargon that only made things more confusing and harder to keep track of since it's not using actual SCP terminology. 

I really like the idea of this game, but it just didn't click with me because of some of these questionable design choices. Personally I find that UI design and "readability" can make or break an otherwise solid game, but if these things don't bother you so much, I still would recommend at least giving this a try so see if the core concept clicks with you despite the confusing aesthetic choices

Lay out your wiki pages, this game has issues. People seem to be misinterpreting this entirely. If you're not running wiki pages side-by-side, you leave everything to chance. Running a day back because an abnormality decides to kick you in the shins is still a time-waster.

Let's start with the basics:
Requires mods in order to run efficiently and mods for quality of life.
25-75% chance (4 Work-types) to be insta-killed for using the wrong work-type.
50% chance to be insta-killed for holding a tool for an inappropriate amount of time.

Now onto late-game:
Everything insta-kills, it's a matter of time before you go mad with RNG obsession.

The game's story is great but why buy this when Library of Ruina tells you all that you need to know?

Amazing game. Very tough and stress-inducing.

What a good game. There's a lot of things I liked about this game. Its soundtracks, story, game mechanics, Abnormalities and so on.

It wasn't all good and sunshine, because there were some days that made me suffer again and again, and I made a grave mistake that needs me to restart all over again. Thank goodness there are mods.


In short, it was a game that made me learn true despair and insanity as you see victory within your grasp only for it to disappear over and over again.

139479960.review:
If you're familiar with SCP Foundation then this is a different take on it. Though here instead of escaping a compromised facility we're playing the manager and command agents around to perform work (end result being energy production for which we have meet the quota every day). As you can imagine this kind of operation can go horribly wrong in many ways...and oh boy it sure does. Every single Abnormality is dangerous in some way and it gets ever crazier with each new day as our department expands getting new additions. We can either go through trial end error to get necessary research on each "subject" to manage them properly or try to check the wiki online, although that doesn't guarantee escaping dire consequences of sometimes merely having some Abnormalities in the facility. To make things more tense we will be attacked by random Abnormalities just entering the facility on daily basis so we will have to focus on more than our own containment chambers.
I presume it's part of the appeal that we will face a lot of failure, will have to restart a day or whole 5-day period to perhaps select more manageable Abnormalities. I can tell we can either focus on our agents to keep them high level and well equipped or just keep hiring new lambs to slaughter in containment chamber as, in the end, produced energy is all that matters (or does it?). Even though things roll out very slowly and consistently it will become overwhelming for someone not very into this idea of Management Sim and certainly feel grindy given we are always doing the same thing but more with extra strings and chances of things going apocalyptic attached each time. 

I haven't made it that far myself given as it turned it's a bit too much for me but there is some truly deep lore in here. Story is certainly a great focus in here and upon looking it up I have no doubts about it. Between each day we have visual-novel style of dialogue with various AI's helping in the facility, always keeping the creepy and uncertain tone of this entire operation. It sure is to keep the player on their toes at all times.

Sadly I can't say more given it's not as for me as I thought but if it seems it might be for you I say go try it. I can totally see what it's going for and it's very much well done - a beautiful, apocalyptic mess for a gameplay and grant mystery to unravel for a story. On perhaps a plus side there are no achievements so nothing to worry to be stressed over if it affects anyone.

Lob Corp, the game that sent me down the PM rabbit hole that ultimately made me PM's personal little bitch and further proved that a toxic relationship would be my undoing because I cannot peel myself away from this game as it infiltrates every passing thought I ever had. Exposure to this game will corrode your very mind.

Lobotomy Corporation is a cute little management simulation made by a handful of students, spare change, and a dream. As it says on the tin you manage monsters, keep them happy*, and stop them from breaching. With every passing day you learn a little more about the world that Project Moon has beautifully expanded and its denizens, every character and abnormality has a story to tell. Just as you think you have it all figured out, boom, more story and possibly murder**

!!!  Just a little warning to all future lob corp players  !!!
1. You cannot complete everything in your first run of the game, but worry not, resetting to day one keeps all your mission progress and collected items and research, it took me many a day 1 reset to get what I needed done
2. Daily resets are your best friend when it comes to learning with how to handle a new dangerous creature, you sacrifice some people, acquire knowledge, scribble it down or commit it to memory, and restart the day. You will lose research progress but you get your little lambs back and you have your actual knowledge to fill in those gaps. There are a LOT of factors that can be taken into account with handling abnormalities so there is no shame in restarting the day
3. READ, project moon fans are well known for their inability to read, I can confirm that this is true for I am illiterate. This game has a massive story*** and it's all very charming, but reading the information presented to you will help you fulfill your duties as a manager. Better get to exercising that brain of yours my friend, it's your greatest weapon in this game.

139127559.review:
tl;dr: save yourself the trouble, this game is mindless grind in the worst kind of way, watch a youtube playthrough before you play Library of Ruina if you want the lore before you play it.

This game is cool. It is not good. I enjoyed my time with it, but I would never ever recommend it to anyone I didn't hate.

The aesthetic the game is going for is SCP. The reason SCP functions as it does, with as little faults as it has, all without breaking the veil, is because the Site Directors are able to delegate tasks. If the site director had to direct each and every researcher to *perform research* on a given SCP they are assigned to, via some kind of PDA, the Foundation would never have gotten more than one Site.

That is to say, a Chain of Command is NECESSARY for the proper and smooth operation of ANY operation, especially one that deals with anomalies, or "abnormalities" as this game calls it.

You play as a Site Director who has never heard of delegation, or is otherwise not allowed to engage with the concept by your AI boss. In the beginning, when you only have one sector to oversee, it seems fine! its just 3 or 4 abnormalities to look over. It might even be a little fun, researching each abnormality as they get dropped into your sector. Like unboxing some weird, supernatural lootbox. You live and learn, sacrifice a few employees in the name of the greater good, but at the end of the day you're a net positive for humanity. You get the personal satisfaction of laying the anomalies bare, knowing all that they are, and how best to suck them dry so Joe Shit the Ragman can watch TV in the gutter.

Then you get another sector to watch over, with the same nitpicky oversight that one would expect of an overseer of a single sector of XK-class anomalies.
"Well," you think, "it's only another sector! It's a single player game! Surely it is balanced around one person playing it!" 
So you endure the more difficult, but still manageable workload.

Then there is another sector. With the same amount of abormalities.

"Okay, this is kinda a lot for one person to handle." you think.

So you endure, mostly crutching on your fully researched clutch of anomalies to meet your energy quota for the day, while still trying to do what you can to research this new and infinitely more volatile class of anomaly. 

Then you get another one.
And another one.

And another entire floor after that, a clone of what you started with, with twice the amount of anomalies dropped per day, while youre still desperately trying to milk your original MAYBE 6 or 7 that you're confident enough with to milk dry (STILL manually milking btw, 3 clicks per ~20s, PER ANOMALY, (4 per sector, and you have 18 anomalies total at the point that you get a new floor, including the 2 it gives you when the new floor is forced on you) while remembering they exist, while also trying to manage deaths on the newer sectors, and managing escapes from anomalies you haven't had the chance to research yet). 

If this is hard to follow, its because it FUCKING IS HARD TO FOLLOW. It's not hard in a fun "oooh, okay so I have to do this to get this to do that" way, its hard in a "ok so i have to trial and error every anomaly that's dropped into this place, restarting 10-25 times per anomaly, if I want to not replay the story sections 800 times each attempt by playing until you literally dont have the manpower to play anymore then restarting from day 0, doing EVERYTHING again with the same research levels, arms, and armor, I got from losing the war of attrition with the game last run" way.

From what I hear, Library of Ruina is pretty good. If you're playing this game to understand that game, do yourself a favor and just watch a youtube playthrough. This shit is NOT worth it, I've been trying to play this game on and off since June 22, 2018, because every time I look at it I think "Surely it wasn't as bad as I remember!" and every single time, it is, if not worse.

tl;dr: save yourself the trouble, this game is mindless grind in the worst kind of way, watch a youtube playthrough before you play Library of Ruina if you want the lore.

138804182.review:
I played this game after I finished Library of Ruina. I think this is important to mention since after finishing LoR as one of my favourite games, I was coming into this one hella biased and you'll get bit of that in this review. I should also mention that in the time of writing this review, I did not finish this game yet, however after 90 hours I feel qualified to share my thoughts. 

You play as a power plant manager. You probably heard about solar powerplants, hydroelectric power plants, nuclear power plants... Well, here you make power from monsters called abnormalities. You also get few very friendly and not weird at all AIs to help you with your task.
It's hard to not compare the story to LoR so I'll compae it. I think I have issue here because I played LoR 1st. I find it very sad that you only get a very little about anything that is happening outside the facility. I beleive this is only because I already knew how amazing the outside word is and maybe it wouldn't even cross my mind without that knowledge. While youi dont get much about the world, you get to know all the AIs working in lob corp quite well. All of them are very, VERY lovable (especially my boy Netzach, I love him so much). I was already familiar all of them before playing this game, however seeing ther story here brought them much more depth.

The gameplay is simple yet complacated. Simple becuase all you do is pick an employee and assign them work. The complicated part comes from managing a large number of abnormalities at the tame time. It's easy to remember that you can't send employee to work with a specific abnormality since they don't have effectiove armor againts it's attacks, however you might just overlook it if at the same time you must,... oh I don't know, pick up tickets every 2 minutes, be carefull to not send this guy to work since he is sparkling a bit, not hold that item for over 30 seconds, find and shoot different abnormality since the work you assigned few minutes ago did not end up well, checking how many of the random-ass NPCs died so you can prepare for a meatball to murder your entire department and do all that while LISTENING TO THAT FUCKING FETUS CRY... ugh, sorry got carried away a bit there. Fortunetly the game does not throw all that at you at the same time, your day norrmally starts with you choosing a new abnormality. This means the game gives you day to learn the quirks of the new abnormality so you are used to it the next day where you are learning about the new abnormality for that day. What I can complain about a bit is the tool days. The days where you find tool abnormality are basically just like the day before except you'll send one person to use do tool, most likely die, reset the day and do the same thing, just without dying. After that, I ended up not using 90% of the tools after getting the max research on them. but there is a thing that is more boring that tool days, those are the days where you... don't get anything. You play the last day again without even the minimum of researching the tool you got. Hoever you can normally do this quite fast and get back to researching new fun abnormalities.
Once in a while the game will throw some challenges called core supression at you and man... those are dufficult. I'm writing this after attempting Binah core supression for a while and well, it was so hard I decided to restart from day one. However, even restarting from day 1 won't fully reset your progress since you keep all the ego (weapons and armor) as well as permanent upgrades and abnormality research. This means that even if you get stuck, you don't have to feel bad if you need to reset to try and get to the same point with better gear (and knowledge).

In the end I don't think I can do anything else but reccomend this game. If you don't enjoy the managing simulatro gameplay you probably won't like it but if you do, this is the peak. 

Also the music goes hard.
