138317630.review:
Day 1: Religion.
Day 12: [REDACTED] is cute!
Day 24: I take that back.
Day 29: There's nothing there to worry about.
Day 36: Legs Undertale?
Day 44: I am no longer a god.
Day 49: Am I having a heart attack?
Day 50: *Flips Table*

I'm going to put this out front, if you don't like grindy/monotonous games, don't get this game. The 'retry day' button will be your best and closest friend right next to 'memory repository.' If you don't grind for the gear, the levels, and to complete missions, you're going to have a rough time. 

Most of the tutorial is 'do this and only this' but it's good for people who don't have a clue as to what they're doing. All the extra information can be found in the manual, alongside some sweet sweet lore. Such as the reason the clerks carry a handgun, of which they're told is for self defense, but they'll learn it's use "when the time comes." (;  However, I encourage those who have friends who have played the game before teach them the basics outside of the tutorial levels. I have taught some new players over Discord, it's time efficient, and less confusing.

The story is, in my opinion, the best part of this game. They have explanations for nearly everything, including why everything looks cute and cartoony. The characters and their development is fantastic and satisfying as they talk about their backstory and you learn about their personalities. The fact that most of the Abnormalities and the story itself is based off of various books and literature.

Unbeknownst to many, this game is for those who enjoy improvement through failure, and the roller coaster of emotions that comes with. And trust me, I mean it when I say that. One day in the game will be peaceful, no Abnormality breaches, no Agent deaths, and man, you got all the easy Ordeals! Then the next day you get a funny looking thing you can have your Agents work with. It hasn't done anything all day, and you decide, "Well, seems harmless. There's only 86 seconds left to fill out it's log, so let's just get that out of the way while I train my Agents." Then your AI's are spamming you with reports, all you can hear is wind and static, and as you sit in your silly little manager's room, everything on fire around you, you check the last bit of the log that was just filled out... "Past 90 seconds of work the employee dies and all breach counters are reduced to 0." It is at this point, you close the window, and sit there as everything burns. An occasional "Hello?" is heard in the vast reaches of your facility as you smile and sit in silence. The lights go out, frames drop to 0, and your hot AI Secretary comes in to tell you, once again, that you're a failure of a manager. Yet for some, ungodly reason, you manage the strength to hit ESC and then slap the 'Retry Day' button once again. 

It is at this moment, you will realize you love this game. All of it's horrible auto pathing, the micromanaging of your Agents in a fight, the neutral music, and gloriously anticipated moment second trumpet drops. You'll smile, laugh, cry, and feel like you're having a heart attack on day 49 like all the other fans of the game. And maybe you'll find yourself repeating the process over and over again like me.

TLDR; Hot AI Manager, Juicy Lore/Character Development, Time Travel, Frames Drop to 0, Lots of Death, Da Capo Al Fine.

138170129.review:
Really fun game. I heard people describe it a lot as being unfair, unforgiving, hating the player, ETC. and that stuff kind of made me think it sounded like it'd be unfun for the sake of being tough, but actually... Most things happen for reasons you can play around, avoid, or be on the lookout for, and the ability to restart a day with what you've learned really makes it feel like Learning the game, rather than just being destroyed again and again for no reason. 
Plus, there are a good handful of different things to motivate gameplay and interacting with things out of your comfort zone, which I appreciate. Abnormality gifts add some priority to try and get your workers interacting with more than just whoever's easy to access and deal with, and the ability to train a worker's stats by using the related work method means there's incentive to have workers do things you know another would already be good at.

If you have any sliver of interest in this game, I'd say pick it up and try it out. This is the type of game that makes me remember why I enjoy games. It's a good experience.
I know I only have 10 hours, and I haven't even reached the midgame, but I've really enjoyed every moment spent with this game so far, so I can easily say I recommend it.

It was also enjoyable to listen to the banger music while crying in the fetal position because I couldn't clear day 49 due to my lack of skill. For sure a game that I recommend trying out if you have the time.

Let me say this first: There's a lot of RNG. But other than that, if you're willing to admit defeat and reset from time to time, you are able to deal with the main shit this game can fling.

For me, it's easy to ignore said shit, and behind it lays an interesting "jenga-like", where every abnormality slowly builds up your employees, your experience, your gear (for the employees) and your knowledge. You can replay the day, you can rewind to an earlier state or just go back from the start with all the gear you had and the knowledge collected. There is barely any time pressure, [spoiler] other than a few missions and abnormalities [/spoiler] so you could also leave it be for a moment and return. The music is in my opinion really good, if you enjoy listening to songs on repeat. The art direction is clear to see where they are set and where they diverted.

This game is not for everyone, but it's definitely for me.

137950993.review:
[h1]What in the world did I just play and why did it work?[/h1]
82 hours to get the true ending in this roguelite management rng-fest (yes, that's the summary you're gonna get). In short:

The good:
Story, worldbuilding
Gameplay
Boss fights (in a management game hell yeah)

The neutral:
Music
Grind

The bad:
RNG

[b]Story[/b]

Without the story, this game wouldn't be nearly as good as it is. But puzzling together what happened in a lab in the Outskirts, and why that relates to gaining energy from monstrous creatures called abnormalities, while assisted by humanlike AI called Sephirot (all with their own personality and problems) is very enjoyable. The story is given in bits and pieces, out of chronological order and altogether vaguely, which leads to a rather intriguing task of figuring out what went/is going on.

[b]Gameplay[/b]

The gameplay sounds rather simple. You have employees who you can send to work with abnormalities to obtain energy to fill the daily quota. Depending on the employee, the abnormality, the type of work and RNG you will produce more or less energy and the abnormality will or will not get more unhappy. If an abnormality is fully unhappy, bad things happen ranging from employee deaths due to abnormality breakout to... more deaths usually.
The interesting part is that after working with a number of abnormalities, a meltdown occurs. Either, it puts a qliphot meltdown on some random abnormalities which can be removed by working with them, but makes them unhappy if left unattended, or it spawns an ordeal in your facility, forcing combat.
Combat, due to ordeals or escaped abnormalities, can go from simply sending in a blob of high-level employees to micromanaging to avoid attacks, depending on the threat you're up against. All in all, the gameplay loop is nicely put together.

[b]Boss fights[/b]

There are no story spoilers here, but I wanted to tag it anyways.
[spoiler]Boss fights, also known as Sephirot meltdowns, introduce a gimmick for a day and reward you with a buff if you beat them. They are varied and a nice breakup of the regular gameplay loop, and several of them are quite challenging (especially the final boss gauntlet).[/spoiler]


[b]Music[/b]

Although it's nothing special, the music is fitting and doesn't disturb the other elements of the game.

[b]Grind[/b]

Yes, it's one of those. You level up employees by working with abnormalities, and in principle days are infinite. You almost have to level agents further than you would just by reaching the quota, since later boss fights require a bunch of high level employees to deal with everything going on at the same time. Furthermore, to get true ending, you need to have seen every abnormality and filled out their entire bio. This'll take at least two full runs, likely three since RNG isn't in your favour and your first run isn't likely to get all the way to the end if you're unprepared.

[b]RNG[/b]

Oh boy, RNG. The energy you get from working, which abnormalities you get, which ordeal you get, where the ordeals spawn, what abnormalities get a qliphot meltdown, this game is jam-packed with RNG and at several occasions good or bad RNG is the difference between succeeding and having to retry the day (I'm looking at you, Queen of Hatred!). Especially bosses can be highly dependant on a role of the dice, with a wrong role almost forfeiting the attempt.

[b]Conclusion[/b]

Story is good, gameplay is good, until you get to the third run and start to prepare/(grind) for the final boss gauntlet. It's rewarding to complete though, and the story makes most of it worth it.

137765326.review:
TL;DR: We love lobotomy corporation

This game is truly an "experience". Before I say anything else, I just want to say this was a wild ride, and I'm impressed with what I got vs. what I expected.

So this was my first "micromanagement" game, and I really didn't know the suffering I was in for. This game really packs a punch with it's difficulty, especially towards the end of the game. That being said, the game simply presents itself as is, and the player is left to adapt to it, and by the time I had played the game a couple dozen hours, I truly felt much more competent at the game.

I also really liked the idea of resetting being integral to gameplay, because it really teaches you to appreciate the overall picture more. I wish that the game urged players to do this more, because this is not a common feature amongst games. One of friends actually quit after getting all the way to day 47 because he had never really known why using the memory repostiroy feature was useful, choosing to instead start from day 1 any time he wasn't satisfied with where he game was going.

That being saidI have a few qualms about gameplay, with the main one being that 2x speed is the maximum setting for core gameplay. Around 20hrs in I gave in to just getting a 5x speed mod so I could avoid grindy parts, such as using the memory repository feature to discover new abnormalities. There are also some things in the game that irk me someone, like a certain minion of an abnormality that likes to grab you and one-shot your employees when it revives every once in a while (you'll know it when you see it). Or enemies having ridiculous attacks that are near-unavoidable. Or a certain someone limiting your use of the speedup button.. 

Regardless, once you tough through it all, you feel that much better about winning, and that's what counts.

Overall: 8/10

Because it's a bad design and no one should have to deal with this "idea" from this dev.
I can not and will not recommend this title or any from Project Moon when they will willfully and knowingly place mechanics within their game/s with potential of clearing save data, specifically the abnormality:

[spoiler](O-05-47)  //  a.k.a Don't touch me  //  a.k.a. The Big Red Button[/spoiler]

This specific encounter when activated kills every member of your staff, so okay no big deal you can restart. However for those who are inquisitive "which is what this kind of game should encourage" you're met with it crashing your game causing a save state of the game there by deleting all your EGO items "employee equipment which you can earn from the abnormalities". The common solution among users and people who do support this "mechanic" is don't pick the abnormality, to which I pose the question. 
Why does it even exist if that is the intended action in a game based around exploration and experimentation?

The simplest answer I have came to, is it's lazy at best, at worst it's designed purely with malicious intent to punish people who are unfamiliar with this specific scenario in a way that is by no means fair in any context of gaming. At either case it's shoddy work on part of the developer to consider this a feature. Through the beginning of the game your fed the concept of "memory repositories" basically save states you can roll back to in case you screw up etc. Then later in the game "Depending on when you get this specific abnormality, all the pushing of this save state mechanic means nothing as when you first click it, "as stated earlier will kill all employees followed by releasing all other entities that are capable of escaping from their containment rooms." Now this in itself as I said isn't so bad, you can reload, but with the new player having had this idea / design pushed at them will undoubtedly "as many did" keep clicking on it to see if they can get any more information from it before reloading, this in turn crashes the client and saves your current EGO gear "which if you weren't following along to this point is actually ZERO at this specific moment in time since all your employees just died before crashing." This could equate to merely a few hours of lost progress, or on a more sever scope, many many days of progress "double so if you are on one of your *NG+* play throughs as it will delete ALL equipment your employees were using when they died."

I discovered this "feature" when I was only a couple hours into the game when it first released, and encountered this information on a post elsewhere and in the fact of not losing progress decided to shelve it to wait to see if it might just be a bug". Fast forward 2 years after launch, still a concept / feature within the game, this of course led me to shelve it practically permanently. Fast forward to now FIVE years after it was launched and they "the devs project moon" after even going on to make another title, with talks of yet another one, still think this is an acceptable feature. Suffice it to say, I will not support any future work by them, if they wish to troll a player base perhaps they should go to making mobile games instead or something, cause they have definitely missed the mark with this gamer with such trollish design.


Now that my bit is aside, the game itself "with that caveat aside" least from my 2 hours, wasn't bad, the main themes / music can get a bit drab and repetitive after a short time however that is easily fixed for anyone on a PC. The toon styled characters and entities are quite sharp and well done, and the basic mechanics weren't to terrible to get through to get started. 

Unfortunately I really was looking forward to this game when I first saw teasers and screen shots, for anyone who likes SCP inspired works, a management sim sounded like a great game concept, only to be ruined by poor choice during it's development..
Absolutely Do Not Recommend

137663260.review:
I would like to preface with two things: I am not a fan of management games, and I am not a fan of SCP. With those two things said, this game was not very fun.

Gameplay:
Playing the game blind involves an extremely unpleasant amount of trial and error. Each anomaly has its own quirks and will kill your agents if they are handled properly. The only way to find this information in the game is to guess blindly. If you guess wrong, your agent probably dies and you probably have to start the day over. If you guess right, you can potentially unlock some information about how to properly handle the anomaly after a few more attempts. Sometimes, what seems like a correct guess is in fact an incorrect guess, which you can't know until unlocking more information, and will likely result in the death of several agents.

Some anomalies deal sanity damage in addition to/instead of physical damage. This sounds great, because it means that your agents won't necessarily be dying left and right, but depending on your agent's stats, it can be worse. Particularly, this can cause them to sprint randomly across your facility, making your other agents insane if they stick around too long. With early game equipment, it is technically possible to bring someone back to sanity, but it's impossible if they're moving too quickly to hit, as is the case with any agent running around.

The game has a research system. Each day you can pick a different upgrade. Notably, the ability to see your agents' HP and sanity on the main UI has been locked behind an upgrade which at the earlist can be gotten at day 8 - meaning, before day 8, the only way you can see your agents stats is to open one of the anomaly work menus. This is fucking annoying, and slows the already boring pace of the game down even further as you obsessively pause and open the menu to make sure one of your agents doesn't get stabbed to death.

Every time one of your dudes goes into a cell to perform work, they get a stat boost. Grinding these out is a mostly risk free way of leveling up all of your guys, but it just takes way too long and isn't fun or interesting. I get to pick options on menus and wait for 30 seconds. Thrilling. I hope no weird robots show up and stab your newbies.

Story:
At the time of the review, I haven't played for too long, so I can't speak much to the story. My impression thus far has been pretty underwhelming. The story exists in two parts: each anomaly has its own little block of lore, and you get to chat with some of your coworkers between work days.

The lore for each anomaly is entirely self contained, and I think (?) is the main draw of the game. This game was made for people that think SCP is really cool. I think it's kinda cringey; oh, what's that? This is a floating skull that likes it when you confess your sins to it? Cool. Oh, this epic bloody bird doesn't sing and has teeth? Epic. This cringe deviantart OC does something or other? I don't care. Amazing storytelling.

The actual continuous story between days is equally dry. You get to have a little chat with the main AI lady, she asks you a question and the only answers you can pick from are the wrong ones, and none of them really change how she responds. After that, you get to chat with the department heads, who don't seem particularly bothered about their subordinates dying or going insane. Maybe the story is about spending time with them and turning them into loving caring people (or AIs, I forget), but I find it more likely that actually we were the bad guys the whole time.

The whole premise of the game is that you're the new manager of some facility that generates energy (???) from working with the anomalies. Why this is necessary or a good idea is entirely unclear. The nature of the gameplay mechanics in an in-universe sense is entirely unexplained. Why does entering a certain number of cells to perform work cause random other cells to maybe have bad things happen to them (e.g. escape) if they're not entered within 60 seconds? Why does it also sometimes cause weird robots to show up and start stabbing people? IDK. Completely unexplained. It's a gameplay feature, I guess.

Summary:
I don't like the game. The gameplay is slow, it either wants you to just read the wiki, trial and error until you kill your agents, or restart the day until you figure out the particular preferences of each new creature. The story is weak and uncompelling, the music is repetitive, the art is ok, I guess, and customizing your dudes costs more of your bonus points which are the only way to upgrade your agents other than just grinding. Ugh. If you really like management games and you're big into SCP, this game might be for you. Otherwise, probably not.

137643058.review:
In short: Story and lore of this game are AMAZING. Not simple, convoluted even, I would say, but great if you give it a thought. One of the best universes I dived into. Gameplay, though, is extremely hard, grindy, controls and UI are also pretty bad. The overall expreience is weird, since it's pretty unique and absolutely fantastic if you'll get engaged with the story, but otherwise - is utterly terrible and seems like a torture. But for me, as I've said before - it's one of the best universes I dived into.

Now for the long story:
As a person, who likes story-rich games with lots of lore to get into, this is one of the best games (series of games) I ever played. I love the story and characters a lot. You can even dive into philosophy and think about life, society and developing as a person.

Gameplay-wise it is pretty bad, honestly. UI is pretty convoluted while game mechanics are very simple, yet they require you to memorize a lot of stuff. Control over the characters is disasterously inconvenient - you quite often need them to stay at an exact place, but you can only tell them to go to the specific room, not place. In some(many) cases this micro-control is very needed, but unavailable. Also, the game is very-very grindy and no matter how much you grind it is still extremely difficult. Like, really over the top difficult. You will save-scam A LOT and it is designed this way by the devs.

Surprisingly though, if you will manage to overcome all those difficulties and will do it all by yourself (I, honestly, didn't have the nerve), you will feel SO much in character with the story and this is one of the coolest feelings I had with any game. This experience is very unique and makes you so engaged with the story. Once you get past that point - you are a most likely a fan of the Project Moon universe.

The game is not for everyone though. The story is very difficult to understand and leaves you deep in thoughts a lot by the end of the game. If you like this type of experience: when you have to deserve your happy-ending and especially, if you like to think about the story, philosophy and lore a lot - you will like the game, just give it some time to tell you major stuff. Because at the start, you don't really get much important info (You don't know enough to understand it in the beginning). If you just can't stand the gameplay, you can drop the gameplay and just watch story videos on YT. I don't recommend doing it though, because you will lose that specific and unique feeling of deserving you victory and being in-sync with the main protagonist.
Otherwise, if you expect engaging gameplay with lots of action, well-though strategy, or a simple story - this game is not for you at all, you will get disappointed.

P.S. If you liked this one, you should look for it's sequel - Library of Ruina. There is also some small nice videos on PM official youtube channel and you can also find some official comics somewhere else.

137624769.review:
Finally the """SCP Foundation game""" you were waiting for!

As a manager of an anomalies (monsters) containment site, it is your job (actually, your agents, you command them) to study, understand, contain and... use them. If everything goes well, you will complete your day with no worries...
But things never go as smoothly as you expect.

Sometimes, those anomalies produce effects that you weren't expecting for... A safe anomaly suddenly had a darker side that just killed some of your best agents... Or maybe, that city-eating monster just escaped its chambers. It is your job to find ways to contain them, manager!

Story-wise, the game is pretty good too. It is engaging enough so you keep going back for more about the Corporation and the world it exists in.

If you want to play something different, I strongly recommend it. Just remember, it is not easy! This game hates you and you will hate it too. But you will love it in the end.

(PRO-TIP: After playing some days, I strongly recommend downloading the mod that shows how much exp each employee is receiving in their work. You can find it at Nexus, it is called 
“More detailed info”.)

137311638.review:
Lobotomy Corporation gives what I, personally, would call an accurate experience of managing an SCP containment facility. Whether that is a positive or negative really depends on your personal preference - it can be quite stressful, especially when you have a lot of needy anomalies in your facility. 
But since the game is a roguelite, killing a run because you aren't having fun is a completely valid choice and is even rewarded, since you retain all of the equipment you have earned so far, as well as the information on anomalies you've already researched. You are also able to just rewind to the beginning of the day, so that you can retry a section if you had too many losses, or to the last "checkpoint", which you get every five days and let you keep all the research and new equipment that you earned.

The biggest con, in my opinion, is that the translations are somewhat lackluster at times and can feed you false information. (If you know any mods that can fix those translation errors, feel free to tell me)

137276503.review:
ballbustingly hard and at times reminiscent of what must be the mental mindscape of a schizophrenic full-dosing LSD after spending a couple minutes staring at the wikipedia entry for the kabbalah, this game is a chaotic and wild ass ride. however, it's also a crucial hazing ritual that one must undertake in order to dive into psychotic world that project moon has cultivated in library of ruina and limbus company.

despite the constant complaints of (albeit justified) difficulty and jank levied against it, lobotomy corporation was one of those very few titles that reminded me that video games can be more than derivative formula garbage. ironic, because it runs like ass despite its looks even on the latest hardware, a lot of the core mechanics are only sort of obliquely elaborated upon in the manager's manual, and the spikes in difficulty are extremely sudden and seemingly impossibly vertical.

however, if you man up and stick it through the rough spots you'll be rewarded with a genuinely unique and memorable experience. this game is the ultimate manifestation of the expression "trial and error", and as such if you're capable of inner monologue it'll lead you into a deep rabbit hole of experimentation laced with equal amounts of frustration balanced out by the inevitable elation you experience when you finally get a bead on keeping an aleph-level abormality content. it's invoked and kindled a sense of wonderment and curiosity that I genuinely haven't felt for a game since I was a child.

if you actually manage to make it through all the way 'til the end, you'll also probably unironically have developed an increased sense of situational awareness, multi-tasking, and a renewed triumphant spirit to replace the despair-ridden husk that once inhabited your soul. the lessons learned from this unhinged and debauched journey will stick with you long after you've closed the game, leaving you with a newfound appreciation for the resilience of the human spirit in the face of seemingly insurmountable challenges. it's a testament to the power of perseverance and the beauty of breaking through barriers, despite the chaotic cacophony of suffering that might surround you. also A did nothing wrong.

137251100.review:
A very fun game that has A Lot of issues with it. There are mods that help a lot with this, giving you information that is needlessly hidden and ways to keep your agents as to avoid needless grinding. The grinding is needless because you can safely grind your character up to max stats without much issue on the early levels of the game but interacting with certain needed mechanics within the game removes your characters. Which causing you to safely waste your time all over again. 
As well hitting glitches multiple times which destroyed various weapons and armors despite using the 'retry' feature which should safely restart the day WITHOUT the destruction previously mentioned. Poor pathing of the units, difficult character selection and grouping, and various other small problems here and there.
There is still plenty of good in this game but it's in such a bad and buggy package that I can't really recommend it.

137223213.review:
Lobotomy Corp is a fantastic story wrapped in a game that tries very hard to apply its themes and logic to gameplay. Many of the gameplay features are explained in-world over time, and there's very few glaring issues with the plot (though you might need to do a little bit of digging to really piece it all together.)

Unfortunately, the gameplay is not very polished. The game is difficult, but often this difficulty is through tedium and pestering rather than actual challenge, which takes away from the experience. There are a lot of very poor design decisions, interesting and neat concepts that were not refined into good gameplay, and the nature of the game means that the majority of them will continue to be a problem throughout the very lengthy playtime.

Regardless, the story is good enough that I would recommend consuming it however you can stand. There's mods that take away some of the more tedious aspects of the game, and unfortunately much of the exposition is backloaded, so unless you have a wealth of patience, consider mods or alternative methods to viewing the story over playing the game in its natural state.

136941354.review:
Gonna keep it blunt with you- this game is tough as balls. You have to micro manage so much to the point the game will crush yours balls and turn it into a smoothie if you forget about one thing. It's also incredibly repetitive to where it will get slightly harder and slightly more difficult each day out of the several you are forced to endure. I also kinda dropped playing it cause it requires a lot of time and it isn't summer yet.

Okay so like why is this recommended? Cause every other element of this game is amazing. Above is the negative aspects of it. For some of the positive aspects:

+ Story and Lore is Easy Highlight- you will find yourself enjoying reading a lot of it. Along with that, ProjectMoon (people who made the game) have two other games that expand on this.
+ You will find yourself eager to actually learn more about what everything does. More in the start of the game you will find yourself forced to learn the traits of each anomaly you hold but then you will find yourself wanting to instead of feeling forced
+ Music is PEAK. Even though you will 90% hear the same two tracks, all the others are amazing such as the warnings. Hell, buy the soundtrack if you don't have a method of listening to them
+ Art is pretty good and really goes over the top with the crazy shit that happens to your agents. Don't be fooled by the fact the people you see in the screenshots above look like gacha characters. 
+ This game is incredibly unique, taking inspiration (or i think so) from SCP but takes a different approach to how it's world is built and how the mysterious creatures/objects are conjured origin wise

If you want to know if you should buy this, I would say it's a game that takes a LOT of dedication for it to shines it's best aspects. If you want a game that you can really get invested into story wise and have the time to do so (check other steam reviews of this game and gauge their amount of hours spent on the game, I barely mid way into game), then this is an amazing game for you. If there is one thing this game requires of you, it's patience. Good game, peace.

136735316.review:
The lack of difficulty settings means that you have to play this game expecting that you will game over and need to restart. Learning by error and slowly progressing, or just having good luck with the entities you unlock. Even so, it's very fun, and I'm a sucker for a good dystopian storyline. 

There's a definite learning curve, where the game pushes you to follow the logic and morals of this world, rather than your own. The goal NOT being to keep as many people alive as possible, but just to finish the day, though more living employees will make your job the next day easier, of course. 

The visual style is cute and simplistic for the main game, with beautiful art in occasional cutscenes that show the contrast of the game-like management position and the reality of the facility. 

If you have some patience and a desire to unravel sinister secrets, this game is definitely worth a try.

136709094.review:
Lobotomy Corporation, if you like games then buckle up because as another steam review once said: "It's a game with all the fun parts removed," and god damnit I could not summarise it better. 

I hope you like hearing the same 5 notes every single minute because that's what you'll be hearing for 80% of the game. 
I hope you like restarting the day over and over because something went horribly wrong, and trust me, a lot can go wrong really quickly.
I hope you like a complete disregard for any ballance whatsover in favour of making you cry and scream.

And above all else... I hope you can cope with the fact that this is somehow fun.

On a more serious note: This game is not for everyone. It's hard, it's unfair but you can adapt and find a way through 95% of the time.
The story is really nice, really messed up too. The artstyle is cute... usually. The OST (EXCEPT THE FUCKING 5 NOTES) is really amazing. 

Being a masochist that played games like Rimworld, SCP:Containment Breach, Dark Souls and other rage inducing titles, I definitely recommend.

136381696.review:
So I went into this because I had been interested in it vaguely for a few years now, and it is on sale. However, what I didn't realize was that the first out of THREE tutorials would be filled with at least 7 different gauges and weird-worded things to keep up with.  This isn't a game.  It's an exercise in reading.  And trying to keep up with at least 7 made-up terms that make no sense whatsoever.  I own over 400 games on this platform, and none of them are as convoluted and ridiculous to try to understand as this is.  It is totally absurd.  I didn't want to buy a book on fantasy.  I wanted to buy a fun game that I could play and try to get better at.  This is an exercise in like college-level memorization.  Idk that I've ever had as much information thrown at me hapharzardly as this game.  And that's saying a lot, since I've played a lot of early access titles.  I cannot begin to explain how confusing and absurd this game is right out the gate.  I'm sure if I spent like 5 hours learning it, maybe I could make some kind of sense of it.  But that's not at all what I thought this was, or what was displayed on the store page.  

This is not fun.  It's not a good game.  It's just an absurd amount of things to try to keep up with for no apparent reason than to make it difficult.  Like there's no story at all.  There's no reasoning behind anything.  It's just "interact with this anomaly to earn points but also unique anomaly points and qhipholphy points to unlock information about it which gives you fortitude points for your agent but watch out for doomagoodness points because then your anomalies might escape where you need gmod weapons and suits to bring it under control which you get from spending qhilophinous points on the anomaly after you have your agent interact with it in one of the four possible ways that they can interact.  Also there are points on your agent and the anomaly to say what will work and what won't work for this specific anomaly."  It's completely ridiculous.  I'd rather read an encyclopedia than "play" this "game."  

And that's after 12 MINUTES OF GAMEPLAY. THERE ARE TWO MORE TUTORIALS TO GO THROUGH!!!!!  I can't even begin to explain the absurdity of this garbage.  I can't believe it has the positive reviews it does.  The UI is ugly, the gameplay is absurd.  

"git gud" I hear people screaming.  I own over 430 titles on this platform and have enjoyed most of them.  I'm not a plebian moron.  This is not for the faint of heart.  And it certainly isn't something to just buy on a whim to have fun with.  This is an investment of time and effort to make any sense of it.  And people should know that.

Edit:  If you notice, even the positive reviews speak negatively of it and the same problems I mentioned here.  Find the common thread through the reviews, and you'll see it.

135879244.review:
Caution: Maybe Spoilers. I tried my best to avoid any major ones.

There are few games that properly evoke a variety of emotions of me, and even fewer than can engross me so deeply that I start to obsess over the next session of play I so desperately wish to do. Let me preface this by saying that this game is far from perfect, and it has a lot of things that people will find annoying or downright frustrating. But for me, that was part of the package of experience it offered and it all fit into place so damn well. For me, this is a perfect game suited to my preferences. I was compelled to write this after having spent 142 hours to 100% the game and attain its true ending.

[b]Gameplay[/b]: It's a management game, but also much more than that. The game punishes tiny mistakes and poor choices of judgement in brutal fashion. The grind in the later parts of the game becomes arduous, making each day feel like a marathon. Those mishaps suddenly feel like soul-crushing events that make you feel either you have to make an immense sacrifice to proceed, or restart the day and accept that you just wasted a bunch of your time. Sometimes, even RNG factors in and decides that your destiny is to fail and there's little you can do but watch on as things spiral out of control. Things like this break the will to play for many people, and I wholly understand this. It's an unforgiving game. In terms of combat, you literally are just a commander that sends units from point A to B. They handle everything else, including any special abilities they may possess. You must simply guide them in the direction they need to go. It's a lot more work than it sounds like, and at some points, the game becomes heavily micro-intensive. RTS players will feel at home.

However, what this game does is reward you in dividends for keen observation, patience, and over-preparation. In strategy games, I'm the turtle player. I overcompensate my lack of tactical finesse by developing a powerful base and producing a bunch of high quality units. This is what I did in this game. And this strategy was time-consuming, and at times, it was tedious. But it pays off. Oh boy, does it pay off. I went into this game 95% blind. I learned things through trial and error. This game, while it does have a manual, doesn't have an in-depth guide to every other intricacy it possesses. For some people, the best option is to browse the web for guides and tips. This is perfectly valid, considering the nature of this game. But I think part of what made the experience so memorable and important to me was being constantly beaten down by unknowns in the game, only to rise up and conquer them after observing and learning from my mistakes. Maybe I'm a bit of a masochist, but the feeling of satisfaction you receive when the things you learn help prevail over a trial you struggled to bypass, the euphoria is exquisite.

[b]Narrative[/b]: This game has an interesting story that is provided through visual novel cutscenes between the days of play. You unlock new cutscenes via simple progression of days, and also completing missions assigned to you. For people that dislike reading visual novels or reading in general, the narrative will probably be a miss for you. There's a lot of reading to do. Even for those that do enjoy those genres, the story is a meticulously crafted one where everyone speaks in a certain way that feels like you're always on the verge of philosophising about existence itself. And most of the time, that ends up being the case.

Personally, as a fan of other series that have similarly overtly complicated storytelling (such as Girls Frontline), this game felt like a natural fit for me. I became so engrossed with the world that they built through the dialogues, and the story of the corporation you worked in. They drip-feed you these details that make you crave for more knowledge, and some characters become unforgettable with the way they poetically speak about their story and how they are now. Lobotomy Corporation is very much a story of facing one's fears to build a future that you can walk into. Yes, the game's slogan is truly relevant at all times. Amazing.

And when it all culminated into the ending sequence, and the true ending... I shed tears. It was full of surprises. I was shocked, but I was also relieved. I was given a victory lap. I was given a sheer spectacle that unfolded before my eyes in a way I didn't know the game was capable of presenting, and I was in awe. A truly beautiful way to conclude a game. I pass my thanks onto the CURRENT english translators (I'm aware of the horror stories of the initial translators) for allowing me to experience this wonderful tale. And let's not get into the chills I got from those final lines...

[b]Design[/b]: This game has a simple style that works pretty well, and it even has an in-universe reason for the way it all looks. At first, you will be overwhelmed by the UI and wondering what everything does. You slowly start to learn how everything works, however, and the important things the game will guide you through via the tutorial. You will likely discover new things about the UI as you proceed through the game, and it can only help you. It is very much a game that, once you become adjusted to the interface, everything then becomes second nature to you.

Mechanically, the game doesn't have many complex base mechanics. You primarily manipulate time, and you manipulate your agents. You order your agents to do work, fight escaping monsters, move to locations, etc. This is the majority of your gameplay loop. The variables which change how these function are the Abnormalities. Every Abnormality is unique, and has its own set of conditions to take care of it. This changes what work you do, when you do it, who works on it, etc. It's here that the game truly shines in how varied it can become and how many decisions you end up making. The game will tell you most things about the Abnormalities as you work on them, so you can trial and error before figuring out the correct method of caring for them.

As for the thematic design, the game stands out. It has a unique artstyle that differentiates it from other games, and every single of the Abnormalities are carefully crafted to be exceptionally unique and interesting. Every time I grabbed a new one, I truly wondered what kind of atrocities it was capable of committing. Some designs are unnervingly cute. Some are absolute nightmare fuel. Some are bizarre beyond our wildest dreams. It's a truly colorful roster of entities, and that's not even speaking about the character cast itself. The Sephirah each have their own distinct silhouettes and characters. Many things in the game take heavy influences from cultures and mythologies, such as fairy tales and Kabbalah. Those that enjoy seeing creative ideas and inspirations flourish, eat your heart out.

[b]Conclusion[/b]: I don't usually write reviews. I don't consider myself much of a critic (even though I'm probably qualified for it in some ways). Everything I wrote here, take it as a different perspective when approaching this game. Keep it in mind and develop your own impressions. This is a game that resonates with a certain type of person heavily. It isn't for everyone, but you can only really determine this by trying it out. And I truly believe the experience everyone else will have will be unique to them, depending on their approach.

I felt compelled to write a review for this because it became one of my all-time favorite games. From start to finish, and even beyond finishing, it has captivated me and captured my heart. To the extent that I know that there will never ever be another Lobotomy Corporation. Never another game that will be perfectly suited to my desires and that would deliver this amazing experience onto me. And that's perfectly fine, because I already have it right here.

Now, time to hope Library of Ruina will also capture me so deeply.

135501872.review:
The game is unfair, the difficulty is artificial. You're expected to die to something you couldn't have possibly known beforehand, restart, and try again. It sounds bad, but it's actually satisfying. Dying over and over again, learning and not repeating your mistakes is the core mechanic of the game. "Oh, this guy does a ton of black damage, I better have black resistant armor on whoever is working with him. Oh, this guy breaks out if I do X, but calms down if I do Y." That sort of thing.

The story is great, I haven't come across anything like it before. I can't really explain any of it without spoiling, but I'll just say that it's a wild ride. Each of the horror creatures that you manage has their own backstory that slowly unlocks as you learn more about them.

A lot of the UI elements are clunky, but you get used to it. You don't have control groups, you can't easily see an overview of all of your agents & their status, you can't chain commands like telling an agent to move somewhere then work on an abno, etc. In order to customize your agent's name and appearance you have to spend an in-game resource (unless you mod that out).

It has some flaws, but overall I'd say it's a unique, intriguing experience that's worth your money and time.

135005294.review:
[b]What worked well:[/b]
[list]
[*] Fantastic world-building.
[*] Interesting and distinctive creature designs.
[*] Unique gameplay model that is fun for management fans.
[/list]

[b]What could be improved:[/b]
[list]
[*] Some questionable design choices, such as requiring spending upgrade points for cosmetic changes.
[*] UI can be clunky and unresponsive at times.
[*] Game starts having major framerate issues when you unlock the middle layer.
[/list]

Other notes:
Even after 400 hours I still absolutely love this game, but it pretty much requires mods for major QoL improvements (do a web search for "Lobotomy Corporation Streamer Mod Pack"). For a first time playthrough, if you want to experience it vanilla then I would recommend playing up to ~Day 26 to experience most of how the game will play out, but then install mods to make the experience MUCH more enjoyable.

134963104.review:
This game has the most unfair, unpredictable, and frustrating mechanics and surprises built into it, to a point where restarting your entire play-through is really encouraged, but the great storytelling makes up for it, and you can't help but keep going to find out what happens next

I do have some other issues with this game though; it's held together by air and memory leaks and bugs are common, but there are mods and workarounds to tone them down to make it less noticeable

I recommend anyone playing this to go in blind and not use the wiki unless you are really, really stuck at a part of the game. I think the experimentation part of the game really adds a lot of value and room of creativity for the player, for example: (How can I use this to suppress another abnormality? How can I use this to manage another?) Despite all the unfair beginner traps, and not to mention glitches, I feel like my experience could have been better if I've used the wiki less

9/10

134844372.review:
I recommend these following.

Cheat Engine for Speed Hacks.

Basemod (Prerequisite for the other mods)
https://www.nexusmods.com/lobotomycorporation/mods/2
More Detailed Info
https://www.nexusmods.com/lobotomycorporation/mods/47
Permanent Agents
https://www.nexusmods.com/lobotomycorporation/mods/79

Cheat Engine is a must due to the amount of absolute grind there is in this game on subsequent playthroughs, it's not hard, it's tedious, it's awful and it can take you hours if you're not using cheat engine. 
Permanent Agents I recommend for a similar reason, however, if you rush the missions you should be fine without it. I specifically recommend doing the Dusk ordeal mission as soon as you get it if you choose to go without permanent agents. There is an entire other progression system unlocked by that mission that the game just doesn't tell you about.

Lobotomy Corporation is a fantastic game until it isn't. Once you discover all the mysteries all that's left it to do the missions and progress days which will look like clicking between a few safe anomalies to grind power for 10-30 minutes. Which is why you should do your best to progress mission objectives as fast as possible alongside your anomalies since not only do they give you story, they give you buffs, and once the anomalies are all studied there's not much fun to be found.

Back to cheat engine, look at my hours, look at my hours. Probably 20-30 hours of that have been without cheat engine. The rest you can multiply by 5-10. Get cheat engine.

EDIT:

Finally some in game help, you can complete missions and anomalies and rewind time before it ever happened maintaining progress. Meaning if for whatever reason you lost a bunch of people studying something or completing a mission you can rewind time to before it happened, keep that progress, and get back all those lost troops. The only cost being any stat increases on your guys along with new people you recruited.


The gameplay is needlessly time wasting as I've pointed out before. Controlling characters is something you can adjust to but there's no denying it's god awful. Likewise combat is terrible.
Story is great, lore is great. Can't get much further into it because this game could be ruined by spoilers since mystery is a central point (there is one exception).

A related issue is you could get so hard screwed by the game for just not knowing. To various degrees it's layers of BS to it. The lowest layer being that someone dies to anomaly and you get research, this is a central gameplay mechanics you have to send sacrificial pawns. Middle layer is someone dies to an anomaly and you get no research/not enough research. There's a couple I give a pass to because their clever but besides that that's just so uninteractive since a lot of the time these kinds of anomalies just insta wipe you. 

Top BS is the purple noon ordeal instantly killing characters in main rooms and you've been warned. How are you supposed to counter an instant kill for any non-endgame armored, max health characters for this one specific event? The answer is you don't, it happens to you once, you restart the day, and you never leave your characters in the main rooms when you see that ordeal coming up ever again.

Now I may have been going on the negatives for awhile but that's because they're pretty bad and also specific.

Otherwise the story is great. I love the writing for "most" of the lore in game. I think the progression system is extremely unique and good once you understand how it works. 
The artwork is great and most the anomalies feel unique. 
A lot of anomalies also have their own unique mechanics which makes the research side of the game really interesting and fun. Every anomaly is its own puzzle. 
The difficulty of the game mostly comes from the lack of understanding so once you've researched every it's naturally easier to progress even if you day 1 because you know what anomalies serve you best. 
The biggest down there is how vague the game is with outcomes and RNG which is part of why I recommend More Detailed Info. Knowing the levels of your characters is also vital for stat farming and even some later objectives, not base game, you need More Detailed Info for that.


Together I think Lobotomy Corporation is a very good but incredibly flawed game. For me I think it's worth it but for others maybe not. It's a cautious recommendation.

EDIT EDIT:
I'm mad, I was mostly positive about this game until day 46. All you need to know is due to in game mechanics I need to replay 45 days to get the true ending because Rewind to the Memory Repository is an awful mechanic, you should just be able to select previous days. I'd like to stress again this isn't a hard game it's a tedious one. So I've given up (again this isn't even taking into account my 5-10x speed multiplier).

If you want the game for the gameplay I can recommend it, it should last a solid 20-30 hours.

If you want the game for its story, look up the game's story on YouTube, I'd go as far as to say this game is openly disrespectful of your time spent with it.
If you want to read up on the lore of the anomalies look at the wiki.

I mean this wholeheartedly that you should never play this game if you want any of the writing you shouldn't touch this game, just view the writing. The only reason I've not changed to a negative review is because I recognize that the game is super fun before you learn every single anomaly.

134779551.review:
Lobotomy Corp is the very embodiment of a test of patience and knowledge. I have beaten it 3 times with my 1st run needing to retry at Day 1 twice and the rest only using memory repository for farming or when needed. At the beginning, the game can be very difficult as you won't know what Abnos gimmicks are, as such you can make a very hellish facility that with one bad result would spiral out of control. However, you do have the ability to rewind back to days ending in 1s or 6s which can allow you to reverse your decision, though any Abno you picked on those specific days are not reversible outside of a day 1 restart. 

The main gameplay loop is learning the Abno's mechanics, getting it's gear, completing any assigned mission and training your employees. Some of the days can be quite calming with the song Neutral becoming engraved into your brain while, others can be a challenge that test's your understand of the mechanics and allowing you to hear it's good OST. There's also combat which essential ends with you sending all of your employees with good gear to beat down any enemy outside of their chamber. Other factors can be considered like the Abno's attack range and their animation which you can use to help make your employees doge attacks. Though this also requires constant micro management but, once you start pilling up with good weapons you can kill things very quickly so this might not become too tedious for some.

I won't talk about the story aside from it being in my opinion, Project's Moon best narrative though there other products have better character writing. The story creates a good mystery for the company Lobotomy Corporation and unravels it quite nicely, and it's writing for the setting is quite good and leaves it open ended enough that you can fill in the blanks with your imagination. 

Now before you start playing the game I strongly recommend getting the game's modding tool Basemod and install the following mods, Optimisation Mod and Gift Effects Fix at the very least. The game is very unstable and some days can go for a very long time, as such you don't want the game to crash and have you lose all your progress for factors outside of your control. Also some things don't work properly which both Basemod and Gift Fix help fix to a certain extent.

In the end, this game is not for everyone and several parts of it can create genuine frustration however, I hold it in a special place and in my opinion is Project Moon best work so far. Not saying their other projects are bad but, Lobotomy Corporation just captures something special that none of their current work has.

134211604.review:
WARINING! WARINING! WARINING!
Manifestation of gameplay spoilers due to this being a retelling of the story, from my experience.
WARNING! WARNING! WARNING!

Lobotomy Corporation is a game that puts up a heavy facade. You take the role of X, the newly appointed manager of the titular company, Lobotomy Corporation. Your role and goal is to extract energy from "abnormalities," which are monsters that range from sweet old ladies, to skin stealers. To help you with this, you're given an android assistant named Angela.

The game goes along smoothly, you meet department heads known as "sephirot," and by this point they all should seem decently friendly, besides Yesod. That is, until the cognition filter breaks down, giving you a small peek in to the true nature of the facility. Right after that, you get a call from a mysterious man named B, who tells you that the company is not even half of what it seems, sowing seeds of distrust in you, and growing weeds of doubt, weeds that Angela wants to pluck. 

Now with your new sense of doubt, you progress more through the game. By this point you should now see "core suppression requirements" on a bunch of the sephirot's mission pages. Unless you know what you're doing, you most likely will not see any core suppression until 60-100 hour in. I got lucky and realized dusk ordeals weren't nearly as much as they were made out to be. Core suppressions are the boss fights of this game, adding a new layer of difficulty on an otherwise normal day. And the more you beat, the more you learn. 

Soon you learn about the man named A, and the more you learn about him, the more heartless he seems. You also learn of a woman named Carmen, who seemed to be the opposite of A in every way besides intelligence. You learn that Carmen died somehow, how she wanted to change the world for the better, and how she wished to help every person in the city. You learn the sad tale of Elijah, a girl who died out of desperation for attention, Gabriel who was driven mad, Giovanni who was deceived, Michelle who was overwhelmed, Enoch and Lisa who were taken in, only for Enoch to die at the well-meaning hands of Carmen, Kali who died defending in vain, Daniel who betrayed, Garion who was just doing her job, and Benjamin, who left A after Carmen's death.

After learning all of this, you begin thinking that A is the villain of the game. But he's the protagonist, as Angela finally reveals who A truly is, and who she truly is. A is you, and Angela is an imperfect copy of Carmen. A has put himself in to a time loop to get the perfect scenario for the "seed of light," a strange object which holds the power to accomplish Carmen's dream, and bring a "well" to everybody. 

Day 46-47, X meets Abel, another version of him representing a part of his mind that thinks nothing will ever change. Abel tells A to either overcome what he has not, or to stay with Abel and accept defeat. X, of course, does not, and perseveres through the day, all 4 upper layer sephirot going in to meltdowns. 

Day 48, X meets his second counterpart, Abram, who represents his guilt and grief for Carmen. Abram tells X that Carmen is dead and gone, to stop carrying on her legacy, and to just let the facility crumble, with his last moments being with Carmen's extracted nervous system. X ignores him, defeating the red mist a second time, and advancing on, almost ready to finish the seed of light.

Day 49, X meets Adam, the version of himself that represents his god complex. Adam is tired, and wants to finish the seed of light project early. This wouldn't accomplish Carmen's goal, and instead would create an imperfect seed of light, turning every single person in to abnormalities, instead of allowing them to manifest their true selves. X goes through his hardest trial yet to deny Adam, but does succeed.

Day 50, X meets Ayin, the true, original A. Ayin has a short conversation with X, and then sends him off to finish the seed of light. After the day has passed, the facility flips over to get the sephirot in their proper positions (Keter being at the top, and Malkuth at the bottom), and a beam of light shoots from the facility after it breaks through the ground. This beam is the tree of light, sprinkling it's seeds across the city, bringing the perfect ending to the game, which honestly made me cry. However, Angela has a different plan. (I won't say any more, as it will spoil certain elements of the sequel, Library of Ruina. I will say what's said in lobotomy corporation, though.) Angela, filled with anger from the torment she's been put through due to the time loop, wants to live a normal human life. She turns off the tree of light, taking the light for herself and using it construct a library, where she may accumulate knowledge of the world, the city, everything. 

10/10 game, and I don't give that out lightly. Well, at least I don't when I'm seriously reviewing something. It is a jankfest, there are bugs at every corner, but those are easy fixes with mods made to debug the game. Play this game if you want to cry form happiness, conclusion, closure, anger, disappointment, practically every emotion that can make you cry in this game will make you cry. After you're done, play it's sequel, it's somehow better than this.

133961979.review:
Lobotomy Corporation is a very special type of game, one whose narrative is so very closely interwoven with its gameplay that they may very well be one in the same.

It hates your very being. Everything about you. It will beat you bloody. It will anger and frustrate you beyond what you think your limits are. You quit. You return to try again. You repeat the process.

It starts to change your perspective. You realize your employees are disposable to an extent. You lost half the department recontaining that abnormality, but that's fine. You recontained it. You can continue. You hire new ones. You train them up. You lose them.
You repeat the process.

You stop seeing the abnormalities as monsters. They're generators. You prioritize working the ones that give the most power. It's risky, the higher the risk level the more power it gives. You work on the alephs, they're the highest risk, they'll end the day faster. If that aleph gets out, you can't recontain it. It'll wipe your facility.

It does.
Everyone dies.

You repeat the process.


You aren't playing as a manager of this God-forsaken facility.
You [i]are[/i] the manager.


...but, to be less eloquent and more succinct, Lobotomy Corporation is the type of game where it not only expects you to fail (constantly), but weaves that failure to be part of the narrative it tells. It is a hard game, it knows it's a hard game, and it will force you to know it's a hard game. And that's the point! If it wasn't as hard as it is, the narrative wouldn't hit as well as it does!

This does, however, introduce a problem; hard games can often become unfun games, especially if you don't have the time for them. I do not fault anyone who can't put up with Lobotomy Corporation, but I strongly recommend people at least try to. For those who [i]can[/i] put up with it, the game is an experience that's rare to find outside of FromSoft (and I would argue that Lobotomy Corporation is [i]harder[/i] than Fromsoft's Soulsbornes!)

133452417.review:
I have a lot of respect for the people who made this game, and I'll more than happily play their other products, but I just had too many problems build up as I went through the game, but incase you do get the game my best advice to give would be this.

Don't be afraid of replaying/restarting, even from Day 1.
The games expects you to use memory repository, and the only thing you will lose from going back, even to day 1, are the employees that you hired, and the abnormalities you obtained.
However any items and/or information you obtained from those abnormalities is kept.
Mission progress/completion is also kept, even from Day 1 resets, this makes replaying the game significantly easier, so do not be afraid of this, or losing employees.

With that said, I actually have a fair amount of nice things to say about the game, so let's start off with the

+++Positives+++

The thematics of the game are great!
I thought the general aesthetic worked really well, both for budget reasons and as an intentional style.
But beyond graphics, there's a lot of horror vibes, the store description doesn't lie with what it's inspired by, I really liked the SCP vibes throughout.

Speaking of SCP's, the Abnormalities are numerous and varied, I loved how different a lot of them were, and it was surprisingly satisfying figuring out how to manage them all and in the end, profit off them.

The story was also pretty neat, though I can't go into depth about it.
I found my eyes glazing over it a smidge with how it was worded at points, but overall I liked how dark it was throughout and how things played out with all of the characters.

Lastly, the music was also pretty cool at points.
For the most part it was kinda samey unless things were going wrong, but when things WERE going wrong, it got pretty good.

Now onto the 

---Negatives---

The games performance is terrible, specifically as you progress.
What started out perfectly smooth devolved into low framerates as the facility expanded, to the point where even loading screens came close to crashing the game if I clicked or alt tabbed.
This is a problem when you're faced with combat, because when particle effects happen, the game practically freezes momentarily, but everything is combat has particle effects.
Damage prompts, insanity prompts, blood splatters, everything will cause lag if you use large groups.
Now while small groups have their benefits, being discouraged from using a large group because the games performance will just die along with all my lower level employees, feels terrible.
But even outside of combat, scrolling across the facility is laggy, animations get less smooth and for the late game objectives specifically, it just feels awful.

To go more in-depth on combat, it's really simple. You select employees and you can tell them to either go to a location, or attack something, and later on in the game you get bullets, which let you manually target people to give them shields, health, sanity or just kill them if they start to become troublesome.
But my problem with combat is that it's too simple, I cannot tell an employee where specifically I want them in a room, I can only tell them I want them in that room. So when I'm fighting an enemy and I want to move them to the other side of said enemy, I have to select the employee, tell them to go into a room on the other side of the enemy (assuming there even is one, otherwise their only option is to either get hit or leave the room entirely), wait for the employee to move, select them again and tell them to attack the enemy.
It's tedious, it's clunky and it's one of the reasons I disliked when the game decided to delve more into combat specifically.

Speaking of those objectives from earlier, throughout the entire game you're given missions from different people in the facility, culminating in a final objective from them. These started off perfectly fine, but the last few in particular were just awful.
I will spoil three of these in particular but these are not major plot spoilers, just gameplay ones.
[spoiler]Starting with the Disciplinary Team, I don't understand why they had boss fights be the days objective instead of just collecting energy, the game is not built for boss fights as it just devolves into kiting attacks over and over, even with your best units. But for your units which aren't the best, you just kinda have them on the side, lest they die and ruin everyone elses sanity.
It's a boring fight which you cheese either via kiting, or through some other method, such as unleashing Abnormalities to the work for you, which sounds like a smart use of mechanics but it's pretty dull [/spoiler]

[spoiler]Next is the Record Team, this one is just dull. It takes away your ability to pause and manage things (to an extent), but it also removes your ability to speed things up, opting to speed things up gradually as the day goes along. I find this extremely boring, as most abnormalities don't use time as a mechanic, so it just makes the day go extremely slowly, and if you need to restart, you'll feel every second crawl on by. [/spoiler]

[spoiler]Finally we have the Extraction Team, another mission that requires you to finish a boss fight instead of getting enough energy, so what this means is more kiting to avoid attacks. The gimmick with this boss is cool, you cannot hurt the boss until you deal with specific Abnormalities that get put into a meltdown state.
Once they're vulnerable, you have a good chunk of time to wail on them. There are several problems here. She can place her meltdown effect on abnormalities which are already on cooldown, meaning you need to wait unnecessarily before you can send someone to deal with it, and when the boss becomes vulnerable, they stop for a long while, even if they're in a doorway transition where you cannot reach their model. If you do not deal with them in this state, there is a good chance they'll throw out more meltdowns again, all because you literally could not reach them because the game didn't allow you to.[/spoiler]

And going back to general gameplay, I really wish the game had more automation.
A lot of days, I was just going through the motions, it would've been nice if there was some way I could just automatically send people to go do the jobs I would like them to do. Replaying days felt boring, because very little changed, and as the facility expanded, the fatigue really set in.

And speaking of the facility, I mentioned how I loved the variety of abnormalities earlier, but sometimes the game can give you some abnormalities you're just not able to deal with at points.
Some will get out because you have too many clerk casualties, one will get out because you don't have enough clerk casualties, some will get out because your employees are too underleveled or undergeared and in the worst case scenario, you're getting them on days where a checkpoint is set and going back to said checkpoint fixes nothing. Going back isn't bad, but the reason for it can definitely feel bad.

>>Conclusion<<
Overall, there was a lot I like about the game, and it started off real strong, but it just became so tedious and annoying with what I wanted from me later on.
It's not devoid of quality, and it definitely appeals to some people, but I find that it was more annoying than anything else in the later game for me to recommend this personally.

133023120.review:
I can't recommend this game for many, many small reasons that add up to it just not being an enjoyable experience.

1. The game is time consuming. Most of that time is spent watching meters fill up. It's monotonous and dull.
2. The controls are a bit wonky. You can just tell this was not quality development, because it really doesn't handle well. Nothing feels fluid. You have to clunkily select and hand out orders. So much of the time you'll find yourself frustrated that you can't see various UI elements during combat, or the ability to view your own units' stats in various parts is kinda crappy, or the way you can't select multiple units with shift clicking how you'd want to. No hotkeys for almost anything. It's just very clunky and slow You can't move your agents to specific spots in a room, you have to repeatedly tell them to move back and forth to get them to stand where you want them to. It's annoying and just badly designed.
3. This game loves wasting your time with random events(doing the wrong thing with a monster/abnormality, a semi-random Ordeal event) that obliterate the majority of your agents and usually force you to start over. You'll know what not to do next time you play the level, but this game has the formula of forcing you to die basically and then just expecting you to avoid it next time. Rarely does it telegraph these things so the player can avoid it with skill. Just trial and error game overs.
4. UI text is tiny and there's no real option to make it bigger. It's fine during story segments, but it's downright unreadable during status screens or gameplay portions.
5. Game is just littered with poor design choices. The equipment screen is clunky. UI is clunky. Some abnormalities really feel badly designed. The combat is clunky and more difficult to control than it should be.

People insist that the story is incredible, and perhaps it will end up that way. I'm on I think Day 30, and there's nothing all that interesting so far. The writing for the abnormalities themselves are pretty basic and unless you're a really big occult fan or something, they don't really do anything for me.

So in short, I can't really recommend this game because I don't think the average person would actually like it. It seems to be intended for a weird niche of gamers who want a challenge, but one that isn't particularly rooted in skill-based gameplay with good controls, but rather just trial and error, sucking up a ton of time watching meters fill, and remembering what things not to do and not doing them through a clunky interface. I want to like this game more, but it's really not that good.

Edit: To add onto this, I also have to note that this game has a gamebreaking memory leak. The longer you play, the closer you get to a crash. Part of why I stopped playing this game is that I was mostly through a very difficult Midnight ordeal that I had carefully played through only to have the game just crash on me and completely wipe out an hour long session. Then I went to do it again and...it happened again. Absolutely unacceptable for a game that asks for this much meticulous play and time from you for a level to have a crashing problem like this if a level takes 45m-1h for you to finish.

132366788.review:
Super great if you're a fan of rouge-like games where there's mounting pressure overtime. 

Great visuals, great soundtrack, great concept. Game is simple to understand mechanically but becomes ridiculously, punishingly hard to the point where you will likely not complete it unless you both know the game inside out and also get fairly lucky with the RNG; speaking of, Lobotomy corporation gives you a choice of three options every handful of days or so which slowly become more and more "pick the least miserable one." the longer the game goes on. as a plus it is also fairly easy to mod and it's super easy to customize your in-game agents with your own assets you drew yourself by simply dragging the images into your game files; agents only have one skin tone, however, which may pose challenges for certain types of custom made agents if that's a concern you have.

one thing I will say is that if you are into the game series for the story you will fucking struggle. Lobotomy corporation will dump huge cut-scenes full of text dialogue in-between days (that are about 5 hours of footage all together! holy shit!) that in the moment you want to skip to immediately get to the game play, and/or may not even unlock all of because the games so damn hard you never get to the text dumps at around day 40ish. Made even worse by the fact that Lobotomy corporation is /essential/ to understanding the plot of the two other games in the series (Library of Runia and Limbus [?] company) so you have to either watch 5 hours of just text dump dialogue in a youtube comp or struggle through lobcorp in order to play runia and limbus.

great concept and great game on its own, it just suffers from the fact that its sequel is much more lax; meaning people who play lobotomy corporation because they want to understand runia may walk away frustrated because the grueling rouge-like punishment is nothing like the other two games in the series.

132287694.review:
Steam's user reviews are an incredibly useful metric for gauging game quality. They're rarely far off the mark relative to the game's actual quality. Which is what makes Lobotomy Corporation so interesting; it holds a 94% positive ratio and yet I cannot for the life of me understand why. There is nothing about the game that is at all conducive to a fun experience; if anything, it is explicitly, PAINSTAKINGLY designed to waste your fucking time. Made it through this agonizingly long day after tinkering around with that innocuous new thing you got and learned some of the rules of? Oh wait, after the end of the day, it just fucking kills your mook. Whoopsie! Better restart if you don't wanna make what's yet to come even more painful! Oops, forgot one obscure rule of how a baddie works and now your team that otherwise passes the gear check gets wiped out? Restart!

And that's the entire loop. There's no relief to any of it. You play the same days over and over again so as not to trip over the tiny roots that made you fall neck-first last time and all that awaits is more of the same except there's now even more esoteric rules piled on top that you haven't deciphered yet without restarting the cycle of endless save scumming. It's a dreadful, unforgivable lack of respect for the player's time. And being a roguelite (i.e an almost universally terrible genre), you're expected to repeat this fucking torture multiple times. Where is the fun in any of that? Suffering is fun when you know there's a light at the end of that tunnel. Lobotomy Corp doesn't have a light at the end of that tunnel, it's just an endless fucking tunnel. There must be a massive audience of people who have given up any and all respect they have for their own time because a game that in no aspect exceeds a 4/10 should not be sitting at a 94% positive review score.
