132239526.review:
Going to append an asterisk to the above "Yes" to also include "with mods, a lot of patience, and the understanding that there may come a point where you decide to just go look up the remaining cutscenes on Youtube."

I can break down the experience of LobCorp into two separate, distinct stages: discovery and completion. During the "discovery" phase of playing the game, each new abnormality, mission, and even new day is able to be approached with an abundance of caution and curiosity. You are, after all, still figuring out How Stuff Works™ and the game is willing to allow you to fumble through messily enough with a bit of sass and a knowing grin - just don't mind the knife being held behind their back, it's probably nothing. Even when ultimately you come into a predicament that necessitates use of a Day 1 reset: the seed of discovery keeps the player engaged and curious as to just what might come next. A good thing, then, that the answers can be more delightfully twisted than expectation may lead one to believe. It's compelling in a way that genuinely kept me playing long hours into the night past when I should've gone to bed.

The same cannot be said of the second stage: completion. This will come at different points for different folks in their own games - when the veil of mystery has been pulled back enough that all that remains is an intricate puzzle to be placed together over the course of an hours-long grind of known figures and punishing setbacks. Here, where the nervous tension of not knowing if your favorite Agent might be speeding towards an early retirement is replaced with the dull monotony of watching progress bars fill and hoping that (maybe this time around) circumstances won't end up in disaster, is where LobCorp truly becomes a test of will (and navigating sometimes-fiddly controls). Maybe, perhaps, you'll eek out a win and then rewind the ol' Repository so as to not lose quite so much progress as the End of Day screen dutifully reports. By the fourth or fifth time you're doing this: the aforementioned possibility of just looking up the damned story becomes that much more enticing.

I enjoyed LobCorp, but it's definitely not a game I would be surprised to hear someone tell me that they gave up on mid-way through. My own file ended up utilizing a few quality-of-life mods to make the tedious climb back to the final chapter something that I could complete before my interest in the game truly snuffed out from sheer burnout. At time of completion, I was happy to resign the game to fond memories and hope that the sequel has a bit less tedium and just as much unique creativity.

To end this review, I'll share with you what originally sold me on giving this game a chance: there is boss fights. How the hell do you do that in a management sim game? The answer may surprise you! (It sure as hell surprised me.)

131671251.review:
[h1]Three things to understand about this game (no spoilers):[/h1]

[b]1. Go in blind![/b]
Don't do any research, if you can help it.  A majority of the joy of this game is learning it and exploring it.

[b]2. This is a Korean game.[/b]
If you don't have experience to know what this means, it is incredibly difficult and you will grind it a lot.  You'll spend a lot of the time doing the same thing over and over hoping for improvement and defeat will be brutal.  Go in expecting the worst and have fun with it.  (I mean, really this sort of difficulty and grinding should be expected by the theme.)

[b]3. This is a Roguelite game[/b]
This is something I didn't really consider at first.  Roguelites require you to fail fail fail and, as you progress, you'll get to keep a little bit of something for the next try.  Don't be afraid to rewind back.  Yeah, it sucks having to grind through the same stuff again, but you'll have more stuff, a better idea of the game, and the opportunity to make new choices.  Getting attached to what you built and sticking with it when you hit a wall and can't progress is only a recipe for depression.

131612356.review: Despite the difficulties and frustration this game can cause, Lobotomy Corporation has easily become one of, if not my favorite game. Somehow, it's able to make you extremely attached to workers meant to be disposable. It's magic. All of the characters in the game are great, and I've gotten very attached to them. The gameplay, when not frustrating, which it usually isn't, is very fun, and I absolutely love it. And, despite how difficult the game may be, it's also forgiving. Every 5 days, you reach a Memory Repository day, and you can rewind to it at any time, keeping any gear you obtained. This can be HEAVILY abused to obtain High Level Gear, I would know, I've done it before, and with no regret whatsoever. One thing that does pain me about the game, however, is having to force myself to get desensitized to Agent deaths. Every time a death message pops up, I'm very tempted to press the retry day button, though I force myself to go on. That is, unless the death is one of my Department Captains, my little scrunkly wunklies. The Abnormalities are very interesting, too. I haven't seen a single design I dislike, and, for the most part, any deaths caused by Abnormalities are due to your error. For the most part. There are a few RNG parts and unfair mechanics. I also love Laetitia. And Der Freischütz. All in all, I would say that the game is AMAZING. It's story is /very/ intriguing, and I find myself extremely eager to learn more and more about the Lore. Easily my favorite game.

So, I went into this game solely because I wanted to experience the sequel, Library of Ruina, to it's fullest extent. Lore implications and the possibility of characters crossing over is not something I wanted to miss out on.

From what I can tell, there's a lot of people who are dissuaded from trying this game because of the genre. I've never really had any urge to play a management sim game, but I figured "what the hell, let's give it a shot", and I'm so glad I did. Lobotomy Corporation's gameplay is very true to the story, through all the time lost to mistakes or oversights you come to appreciate the Manager's position and how painful the journey actually is. Somehow after all the frustrating resets and losses, I came out the other end feeling truly satisfied. I guarantee you'll love to hate it. Big cope.

130967946.review:
Lobotomy Corporation touts itself as a mix between a buisness/monster simulation and a roguelike game. This description is incredibly misleading. When you think of a "simulation", one would assume that there would be different aspects you control in the game, but those mechanics are completely shallow. And the "roguelike" aspect only comes from the selection of artifacts or monsters you choose from when given the opportunity to do so.

As far as the whole simulation aspect is concerned, there's very little of it. You can "hire" employees, change their equipment and decide what they do, based on the department they work in. That's it. There's really no management of resources, or selections of departments or tools or anything like that.

As far as the game goes, it's very simple, each successful day completed you choose from a new "abnormality" (which is labeled under a serial number). Then you spend the day trying to understand it by studying it while maintaining and containing all of your other abnormalities.

Studying a abnormality is completely a game of guess work and can completely ruin a game until you know what's going on with it. Unless you've watched play throughs and understand what they do and what they need, all you can do is blindly click.

After you complete research of a abnormality, it's just a matter of grinding energy and packages from them. That's it. The first couple of day(s) can be fun, but the longer you play, the longer you realize that's there's actually very little gameplay holding this game together. And it gets boring very quickly.

For almost $25.00 for a "indie" game, I would have really expected a lot more based on what they actually advertise. In some instances I would actually argue their STEAM store page may be misleading and possibly false advertising.

If you can get this game for $5.00 then fine, take a chance. But at full price this game is a full blown rip off.

This is a very difficult game. 
I have over a hundred hours in it currently, and still have not gotten to an ending that isn't the default bad ending, which all but forces you to reset to day 1. 130611863.review:
After giving it some thought, I have come to the conclusion that trying to properly "finish" this game would be an exercise in severe boredom & tedium, not to mention how it would be an unfun timesink of several more hours. After reading some of the almost comical requirements to actually 100% the game (e.g. to get the "true" ending), I've decided to call it here. If I could give a "meh" review I would, but a negative review better conveys my current stance on the game better than a positive one.

My honest recommendation to people considering LC is to please THOROUGHLY research the game (possibly including a bit of spoiler material!) before deciding to play it till the "end". I will try to avoid spoilers below.

PROS:
- The lore/story (as badly conveyed as it is, in my personal opinion) is fairly interesting. This is a very lively world and everything is not at all as it seems when you first start playing. Also, the reset mechanics are tied into the story itself.
- The ideas/characters put into this game are very creative. What you do see of the AIs is somewhat endearing
- The management is initially quite engaging. You have to keep track of a lot, but it is rewarding to clear days with no deaths and well trained agents.
- The research/upgrades in the game make a big difference and are quite distinct from one another, unlike in some other games where its just a "+5% damage" type of system
- The Boss fights are mostly quite varied and challenging, mostly in a good way though this breaks down a bit at the end.
- Some of the music tracks are quite good, others get repetitive quickly.
- The four damage types + weapon/armor variety helps to diversify combat.

NEUTRAL POINTS:
- Music can get very grating after long sessions. This can be turned off, obviously.
- This game would massively benefit from the workshop, but no such allowance was made. Fortunately other modding is possible.
- Sound effects are meh.
- Graphics/artstyle choices are... meh. They don't endear me or push me away from the game. Up to personal preference whether you like or don't like the cartoony aesthetic.
- Some players have reported very serious issues with the possesion mechanic not working properly (e.g. some people that should be able to be un-possesed cant be, and so you have to reset). I have not encountered this so far, but be wary.


=== NOTE ===
Thankfully, some of the issues that will be outlined in the CONS section can be fixed with mods. In fact, issues that can be fixed, or at least ameliorated with mods will be marked with a "[Mod full fix]" or "[Mod partial fix]" tag for your convenience in the CONS section below. However, I am judging the game on its own merits, and not on the those of the modders that gave their time & effort to fix its many problems.
===========

CONS:
- surprisingly Sub-standard controls. The game has the manager exert very indirect control of agents, and No control of clerks whatsoever. This will often lead to completely unnecessary damage/breaches/deaths that are frustrating setbacks or outright resets. As an example, a major strategy in the game is to put agents into elevators so they can be grouped up and thus fight anomalies in clumps of melees & ranged squads... Instead of just letting the player group them in some custom arrangement.

[Mod partial fix] - You can speed up time in this game, but not nearly enough. Eventually even 2x/2.5x is wildly insufficient for how tedious much of the management phase becomes. 

[Mod full fix] - Very poor conveying of (VERY important) statistical information to the player. Part of the game is, obviously, to let the player become a manager of a huge, byzantine facility and make the best of it. LC, however, takes this to excessive lengths. The game plays around with giving the player access to information as part of research/story progression (HP/SP of agents/abnormalities as part of a research from one of the AIs). LC, however, does NOT give info on Shield HP/SP, NUMERICAL HP/SP of agents/abnormalities, NUMERICAL Use-Speed/Range of weapons, NUMERICAL success probability with fully understood abnormalities... This is extremely important information to properly manage the facility!

- Very poor conveying of spatially-related information. The game will not notify you if someone in the facility is taking damage / in combat, nor will it tell you how they died. I suppose this could be a deliberate design decision, but it is one that is hugely irritating to me personally. I much prefer the Rimworld method of alerting you to threats. ALSO, agents can Stack on top of one another, and then you cant easily see their HP/SP

[Mod partial fix] - Many models do not display the correct weapon your agent is holding, which can cause confusion in the middle of an important suppression.

- Again, personal opinion, but the way the story is conveyed is very, very poor. Others might not mind this more "scattershot" type of storytelling.

[Mod partial fix] - Unacceptable performance issues that can cause memory leaks. I was shocked to see >95% RAM utilization (out of 32gb DDR5) by this game one night. Be aware you will probably have to limit your play time to a few hours to avoid this. There is also generally poor optimization.

- No spoilers, but a good number of the ordeals/bosses in this game are simply boring timesinks that are occasionally frustrating and generally tedious exercises in kiting for minutes on end. Late game can be pretty egregious in this regard

- No spoilers, but some abnormalities are genuinely run-enders if you are unlucky with their placement, or just rely on frustrating mechanics to not cause immense damage (Like getting "Normal" results only). Getting enough abnormalities that care about agent/clerk deaths can cause spirals that go on to cause resets as well, though this is eventually mitigated with execution bullets.

- Eventually ~75% of your abnormalities will be completely ignored in favor of more dangerous (more energy producing / more efficient training) abnormalities. I feel this is a missed opportunity wherein we the player have no reason whatsoever to interact with the vast majority of the facility. 

[Mod full fix] - This game is already painfully tedious and (imo) pointlessly time consuming after enough time has gone on that the players has a good grasp of the game. Why can't I queue actions? Some consider this part of the management process, I consider this forced, boring busywork.

- You have no idea how long an agent has been using a tool abnormality and so have to: 1. guess or 2. using a separate abnormality as a makeshift timer or 3. use a real world timer (hope you are not at 1.5/2.5x speed 
 in game!). This has genuinely been a huge headache on every run.

[Mod full fix] - Training employees is a near complete guessing game. Perhaps I missed something, but until I read the wiki outside the game itself, I had not idea how my agents stats were being changed as a result of work/suppression/gifts. This is, again, very important information that the game doesn't tell you. I feel like Im seeing a rather unfortunate trend for a MANAGEMENT game.

- This one is subjective, but I feel the way clerks are handled is very strange and could have done with a some overhauling. Essentially clerks provide you with buffs, some of which are fairly important. But eventually you will probably have to cull very large portions of them (usually with execution bullets) to prevent abnormalities from breaching as a response to too many clerk deaths from abnormalities or other events. So you can:
1. Not cull employees, and so risk breaches, which will probably kill clerks and reduce/lose buffs.
2. cull employees, and so diminish breach risk, but also reduce/lose buffs.
The player is put in a situation where they have buffs when they LEAST need them (start of day), and dont have them when they MOST need them. (middle/late into day).

130523072.review:
Lobotomy Corporation is a difficult game but one I enjoy immensely.

It's a good game to play if you enjoy challenge and have the time to sink into it. 
It's also good for those who enjoy fantasy, management, SCP, as well as watching your little nuggets grow and become the ugliest and strongest possible <3
There is no more joy than watching them grow extra eyes on their cheek, maybe where a literal face mask... yuck! But aw!

The game play is engaging and feels rewarding.
While it definitely has a bit of a problem where if you don't know what you're doing the first time around you may have to restart the whole cycle (which can take a while depending on how you play, and it often requires a bit of grinding), it has the tools to let you explore, try again, and slowly figure out what each abnormality can do.
As you figure out what each one does, you're rewarded with an increases in stats, information, story, and even weapons/accessories depending on the abnormality.
When I see the little ugly nuggets smack their silly pink goo and feather bullets(?!) at each abnormality and destroy them you can't help but feel a bit of pride.

As a reward for progressing and surviving you get to learn the stories of each character, and if you play your cards right, you can learn so much more about them.

Also there's customization
Want to get attached to any of your employees that may die at any moment? Go right ahead! This will not backfire I'm not sad shut u

130096808.review:
This game is not for everyone. It will beat you senseless through repetition, trial and error, and the sheer horror contained within it. It is a game that asks the player whether they truly think it is worth it to simply continue to see an ideal through until the very end, no matter the pain and suffering that is along the way. If you feel like you can withstand a plunge of over a hundred hours into such a task, and be rewarded for your trials only at the very end, then the game is worth looking into for you. This game is as close to human suffering condensed into a product as you can get, you can start off likening your employees to humans in your head, seeing your nuggets complete each day and trying your hardest to keep them alive. Eventually, something will snap in you, and they change from individual to expendable. A way of putting this game simply is that it is training for middle management. 
So basically this game is mainly for those who see suffering as the path to growth, and if you can accept that, this game will be great for you.
Now, finally, after having spent almost five years in my off and on run, I can continue onwards into the Library.
